147244810.review:
Guacamelee es un juego de acción y plataformas que se destacó por su originalidad y diversión. En cuanto a su dificultad, ofrece un equilibrio interesante. Si bien presenta desafíos en forma de combates y acertijos, no llega a ser excesivamente difícil, lo que permite a una amplia gama de jugadores disfrutarlo.

La historia de Guacamelee es cautivadora. Se centra en Juan Aguacate, un aguacateador convertido en luchador de lucha libre para rescatar a su amada, Lupita. La narrativa se desarrolla en un mundo de mezcla entre el folklore mexicano y el inframundo, lo que le da un toque único. La trama es humorística y llena de referencias a la cultura pop y los videojuegos.

La ambientación es uno de los puntos fuertes del juego. Los gráficos son vibrantes y coloridos, con un estilo artístico inspirado en el arte mexicano tradicional. Esto crea un ambiente único y atractivo que se siente fresco y original.

La música de Guacamelee es simplemente genial. Combina ritmos mexicanos tradicionales con toques modernos y vibrantes. La banda sonora añade mucho carácter al juego y se adapta perfectamente a la atmósfera general.

En cuanto a las referencias, el juego está lleno de ellas. Desde homenajes a otros juegos populares hasta guiños a películas y cultura pop, Guacamelee es un festín para los amantes de las referencias y los Easter eggs.

Para mí, Guacamelee es una experiencia de juego única que combina una historia interesante, una ambientación atractiva, música increíble y un buen equilibrio de dificultad. Si bien disfrute más el 2 (Al cual le tengo pensado hacer una reseña más adelante), Sus numerosas referencias, su historia y su estilo visual distintivo hacen que sea una experiencia memorable para cualquiera.

146289114.review:
Guacamelee Super Turbo Championship Edition Review

Review is after completing the main story missions and a few of the initial side quests.
[hr][/hr]


[b]Story[/b]
The story is about Juan (a simple Mexican agave farmer) and his quest to rescue his crush El Presidente’s daughter from an evil undead Charro. The story is simple but the main attraction of the game is its humor and its colorful art style. The game has no voice acting; only having dialogue prompts, but that dialogue is also laced with good humor. Along the way in his rescue his crush Juan meets a bunch of helpful characters who teach him the moves and powers required to become a luchador. It turns out that Juan must become a fully fledged luchador to save his beloved. He also meets a cast of enemies who are also similarly hilarious. Overall it was an enjoyable story that was wonderfully inspired by Mexican culture. 
The only complaint I have is regarding the ending of the game. The game requires you to find about 6 hidden items in order to get the good ending. This only becomes apparent after playing the game and receiving the bad ending. The game doesn’t tell you that you need to find all these hidden areas (in addition to the hidden chests), at least I don't remember any prompts or hints about these hidden areas. Thankfully a good auto save point just before the final boss battle allows players to backtrack through the maps, collect the hidden items and thus get the good ending. I did not fulfill this task as I did not have time to backtrack.


[b]Gameplay[/b]
This is my first Metroidvania style game and so I played on Normal difficulty. The gameplay was very entertaining because it had a healthy mix of platforming and combat. Platforming and exploration required creative use of the various luchador powers as well as excellent timing. Because of this getting to some hidden chests required a lot of retries and button mashing. I was not able to get to all the hidden chests but I managed to get at about 75% of them. The combat was very satisfying, supported by a great enemy variety. The enemies are also colorful and have a variety of attacks. The luchador costumes were also very amusing in their functionality and they are unlockable after earning special coins through gameplay: as it should be! As I remember when it comes to backtracking, all the enemies did not respawn; which is so refreshing, because I was dreading the grind. But fortunately only some of the enemies respawned or was it the enemies I skipped? I don't honestly remember. But either way backtracking wasn’t a slog. Out of all the powers I think Pollo power is unmatched. I won’t spoil what that is but it matches the game’s humor and themes very well. 
As mentioned I did not backtrack to find all the hidden items required to get the good ending of the game. I tried out one of those hidden areas and got the hidden items but backtracking felt tedious. I understand that one of the draws of Metroidvania games is backtracking to previous areas to collect the hitherto inaccessible areas or show those tough bosses who’s the hero of the story. But this is not my choice so I did not backtrack much; I found it tedious after a while. The only annoying part of platforming were the portals. There were some parts at the end where quick reflexes were needed to move forward through the portals. I found this tedious and unenjoyable compared to all the other excellent platforming sections.


[b]Graphics[/b]
The art style was colorful and lovely and subsequently the graphics were also vibrant and refreshing to look at. This is one of those game that will look good regardless of whether you have a low range or mid range graphics card. Backgrounds, enemies, bosses and allies have the same lively color theme. An absolute treat to look at.


[b]Controls[/b]
Played using the Xbox controller attached to the PC. A controller is mandatory for this game. Some button mashing was required at times and at times attacks did not register correctly. So there were some frustrations but they did not prevent me from finishing the game. 


[b]Side Missions[/b]
There are a few side missions in this game. I was only able to complete a handful of these. For most of them I couldn’t find where to go to complete them so they were simply forgotten as I progressed.


[b]Music/Soundtrack/Voice[/b]
The game has no voice acting which I did not find to be a negative. The soundtrack was thematic and adequate and all the funny sounds accompanying power ups encounters and combat filled out the gameplay experience nicely!


[b]Performance[/b]
Experienced no crashes and the game ran smoothly on my PC (which is a mid-range PC). It did not cause undue heating of the CPU and GPU.


Overall Score 8/10

I wasn't planning on playing this until it was chosen as the Game of the Month for August 2023. I like metroidvanias and I figured why not give it a try.

What I liked:
* The colours and the music. It's surprisingly beautiful.
* The platforming sections get more frustrating towards the end but the game is short enough to suffer through some moments. I liked that falling off the stage wasn't instant death.
* Fighting with the different coloured shields takes some getting used to, but it's a fun mechanic.
* Some other mechanics are introduced that make battles interesting to say the least.
* One of your forms is hilarious to me.
* There are some easter eggs of different games (especially the song in the final dungeon ha!) that makes progressing fun to find the next thing.
* Boss fights are fun enough and easy to figure out.

What I didn't like:
* The story was not too interesting and the ending was abrupt to say the least.
* Falling off the stage is fine, when you fall into lava your transported back to the save point...
* Combat gets messy when there are a lot of enemies in the area. Your fall animation is painful because it takes a long time. There's one particular punchy enemy that drove me crazy because of the loop of falling and him beating me I would get stuck in.

It was a fun experience and I can recommend this game for people who liked the mechanics in the Messenger but who would like a little bit less challenge.

142281958.review:
[h1]A tasty taco you won't forget[/h1]

Well well, a freshly-updated version has been launched with a bunch of delicious new upgrades to sink your teeth into.

If you’re not familiar with the story, let me fill you in. You play as Juan Aguacate, a simple farmer from a small town. One day El Presidente’s daughter was kidnapped by Carlos Calaca, an evil demon, and poor Juan tries to stop him, but dies in the attempt. He wakes up in the Land of the Dead. There, he is gifted a magical luchador magic by a mysterious female luchador. He puts on the mask and is transformed into a powerful luchador himself, and is promptly returned to the world of the living. His goal is to rescue El Presidente’s daughter before she is sacrificed as part of Carlos’s plan to merge the worlds of the living and the dead and rule both with a bony fist.

Juan still has his wrestling themed attacks which you will use throughout the world to reach certain areas and take out certain enemies. It is still major fun racking up huge combos by pounding on enemies over and over again. As you progress through the game, you unlock new skills and attacks you can mix into combat, adding some great variety to the battles. Some enemies actually require certain attacks to defeat, so you are forced to adjust your tactics accordingly. Similarly, certain coloured blocks require certain skills to break and progress, so parts of the levels become unlocked over time, and back-tracking is encouraged.

Later in the game you gain the ability to switch between worlds of the living and dead, first through special ‘portals’, and later whenever you want. This comes into play during much of the tricky platforming challenges the game throws at you. If I had one issue with the game, it’s that some of these platforming sections can feel almost too difficult at times – however, it feels fantastic when you finally execute the right sequence of moves to get through successfully. Check-points are quite generous too, so you are rarely set back too far if you die.

What is new this time around is a new “Intenso” skill, which adds another meter next to your health and stamina bars. This bar will fill during battle, and once full enough, you can unleash its power, doubling your damage and speeding you up slightly for a short period. It can certainly come in handy when things got crazy.

Also new to this version are some new elite enemies, including a new boss that is three times the threat – you will see what I mean when you finally come across him. The world of Guacameele! also got a bit bigger too, with some new regions added to the map, including “El Infierno”, which acts as a challenge area to test your skills and reward you with money, experience, and upgrades.

The overall look of the game is the same glorious colourful cartoon like style from the first time around. I love how the game looks from start to finish with its Mexican and Mayan overtones, and there are many funny references to other videogames and memes in the backgrounds. Everything is well-animated and the characters are full of life. The game itself is crying out for its own cartoon series in my opinion.

There are alternative costumes for Juan and the mysterious female luchador (Tostada) that can be unlocked during the game. Also the fan community has been creating their own costumes for the game on PC. Some really cool designs can be found on the Steam Workshop.

While traveling the world of Guacameele! you will still be treated to some great music and audio. Punctuated by Mexican guitars and trumpets, this is a soundtrack that suits the game perfectly, and I’d honestly like to add it to my collection. It will have your heart pumping during intense battles, your pulse racing at epic boss battles, and have you grinning ear-to-ear at the more humorous moments of the game. There still are no voice-overs for the characters, but honestly I don’t feel the game needs it.

In the end Drinkbox studios took an already great game, and made it that much better. So lace up your boots, pull on your mask, and dive head-first into the action! This is a must-buy that will be enjoyed by all. ARRIBA!

140432816.review:
[b]TLDR: INDIE METROIDVANIA WITH A REALLY COOL THEME AND ARTSTYLE AND CO-OP (!!!), PLAY IT[/b]

[b]Guacamelee[/b] is a 2013 indie game (2014 for this rerelease with extra stuff, technically), one of DrinkBox's first games (their third, to be precise).
[i]Though even if I didn't explicitly say it, you could've probably told what timeframe this was released in considering the game's humor and constant gamer references throughout the entire world.
Including that one side villain that, in no uncertain terms, says [b]"Trololololol!"[/b] to your face.[/i]


It's a mix of a platforming metroidvania and a brawler, with simple and easy-to-grasp controls (basic attacks, a grab button with aimable throws, and directional special moves like Smash Bros.) but a LOT to do with those controls.
Progression is pretty standard, as you might expect; you explore areas to the extent your initial abilities allow, and gradually unlock more skills as you play to open up the way to more and more interconnected areas (abilities you get from breaking... [b]Choozo statues[/b], yes this game wears its inspirations on its nonexistent luchador sleeve).

All of your BASIC fighting moves (standard attacks and grab/throw attacks) are available from the start, but you CAN buy some little side upgrades for those from the shops on every savepoint.

Yeah, you get money (Pesos, fittingly) from beating up enemies, as well as silver coins as unique collectibles that can be used to unlock [b]costumes[/b] that (mostly) give special effects and act as sidegrades (one good effect, one bad effect).


Speaking of pesos... Yeah, it's a mexican-folklore-themed game. A [i]VERY[/i] mexican-folklore-themed game. You can probably tell from the artstyle and screenshots already, but both the visuals and the music [i]heavily[/i] help carry that vibe along.
It's a weird mix of that type of theming with 2013-era humor. Obviously not everone is going to [i]like[/i] that type of humor but it's honestly inoffensive enough to not really detract from the overall story and writing (and hell, it's a bit [i]nostalgic[/i] in its own way).


Obviously like any good Metroidvania there's a TON to explore. All the areas are interconnected, and you can unlock teleport spots in (almost) every area to quickly warp from one to another. The map also handily marks walls that require specific abilities to break (the ones you unlock as you go, which are all color-coded for convenience) and keeps track of your item discovery percentage in every area, so you can comfortably head back and check for any small paths you might've missed on your first run through.


This isn't a TERRIBLY long game, you can beat it in about 3-4 hours. I know [i]my[/i] Hardmode run just now to finish 100%ing the game was a little over 4 hours, including all my deaths from... it being hardmode.
Without doing any sidequests (yes, those exist) or going for all collectibles, anyway.

But that's for the [i]BAD[/i] ending.
Yes, without spoiling anything, this game has MULTIPLE endings. You'll be expected to get the bad one on your first go, as [I]right[/i] before it ends it introduces an entire SEPARATE set of Macguffins to collect, all of which will be on entirely new parts you hadn't even THOUGHT were there before. Adds a GOOD chunk of extra playtime. My 100%ed savefile with all the extra content done ended up being about 11 hours long or so.
...Some of those collectibles are also kind of CBT to collect, or even to FIND [b](looking at [i]you[/i], Forest del Chivo)[/b] but hey, that's the point of it being extra challenges to earn the better ending.
You [i]might[/i] need to look up a guide for that specific one though.



Anyway yeah I've rambled on enough, it's a good game and it's cheap. Get it. It's fun, [b]ESPECIALLY[/b] if played co-op.

138100708.review:
Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition es un juego de acción y aventura desarrollado por DrinkBox Studios. En este juego, los jugadores controlan a Juan, un aguacate cosechador convertido en luchador enmascarado, mientras lucha a través de una tierra mágica de inspiración mexicana para rescatar a su amor perdido.

En términos de jugabilidad, Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition ofrece una experiencia de lucha fluida y divertida que es fácil de aprender pero difícil de dominar. Los jugadores tienen acceso a una variedad de movimientos y combos que pueden utilizarse para derrotar a los enemigos. Además, el juego cuenta con una mecánica de cambio de mundo que permite a los jugadores cambiar entre el mundo de los vivos y el mundo de los muertos para superar obstáculos y resolver acertijos. En términos de jugabilidad, Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition recibe una calificación de 9 sobre 10.

En cuanto al apartado gráfico, Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition cuenta con un estilo visual único que combina elementos de la cultura mexicana con un estilo de dibujos animados colorido y vibrante. Los personajes y los entornos están diseñados con mucho detalle y son muy atractivos a la vista. En términos de apartado gráfico, Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition recibe una calificación de 9 sobre 10.

En términos de rejugabilidad, Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition ofrece una campaña en solitario que puede completarse en alrededor de 6 a 8 horas, dependiendo del nivel de habilidad del jugador. Sin embargo, el juego cuenta con varios desafíos adicionales que pueden desbloquearse después de completar la historia principal, lo que proporciona horas adicionales de juego. Además, el juego cuenta con un modo cooperativo local que permite a los jugadores jugar juntos en la misma pantalla. En términos de rejugabilidad, Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition recibe una calificación de 8 sobre 10.

En cuanto a horas de juego, Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition ofrece una experiencia de juego corta pero intensa. Aunque la campaña en solitario se puede completar en alrededor de 6 a 8 horas, hay suficientes desafíos adicionales y modos de juego para proporcionar varias horas más de juego. En términos de horas de juego, Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition recibe una calificación de 7 sobre 10.

En general, Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition es un juego de acción y aventura emocionante con una jugabilidad fluida, un apartado gráfico impresionante y una buena rejugabilidad. Con una calificación promedio de 8 sobre 10, Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition es una excelente opción para cualquier persona interesada en los juegos de acción y aventura con una temática única y colorida.

137109205.review:
[quote]Follow my Curator page, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41363546-Fruit-N-Doggie-Reviews/]Fruit N Doggie Reviews,[/url] so you can be updated whenever I post a new review.[/quote]
[h1]First Impressions[/h1] 
Guacamelee! (GM) Super Turbo Championship Edition was a local coop game that I played over at a friend's house. It's a title I already owned, but when you're trying to find any Steam game with local coop, there's only so many options available. Based on how it went playing with friends, I was slightly concerned about trying it on my own, because even when we juggled health and lives, we kept failing to clear certain fights. Surely I'd be screwed by myself. 


[h1]Gameplay[/h1] 
Taking the role of a luchador, you might assume that GM would be a beat-'em-up or brawler of sorts. With respect to the combat, it more or less plays that way, as you combo and grapple your foes. However, it also has Metroidvania aspects, as you'll return to previous areas with new abilities, unlocking paths that were blocked off before. Most of the moves revolve around combat to some degree, such as uppercuts and headbutts, but they also have relevance to platforming. For instance, when you can switch dimensions, this is needed to create and pass through floors and walls, but also puts you into the same plane as the enemy. Otherwise, they're apparitions you can't hurt, while they can still attack you. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2961799363
[h1]Controls[/h1] 
There aren't many situations in GM where you'll be dealing with platforming and combat at the same time, but with abilities covering both matters, your move set is pretty consistent in either situation. After acquiring so many moves, it can be easy to mix them up, though the mistake I made most often was whether I changed into a chicken or switched planes. It's also theoretically possible to pull off some complicated combos, but I tend to use simpler ones myself. Overall though, I think the controls worked quite well. 


[h1]Story[/h1] 
Having been cheated out of his glory, after making a deal with the devil, Calaca overthrows him and plans on becoming the ruler over life and death. After invading the mortal realm, he kidnaps the main character's love interest, kills him, and creates his own adversary. For it was written that a recently murdered agave farmer would become the luchador of justice. In some ways, I think the villain is overshadowed by his more eccentric followers, as he's a pretty generic foe. Although I enjoyed the story overall, I was bummed that there wasn't an overview of what happened to all of the characters after beating Calaca. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2964826628
[h1]Visuals[/h1] 
Honestly, I love the presentation of GM. It's flashy, colorful, and really invigorates me while I'm playing. You always know when you find a secret or clear an arena battle, because the game does a small celebration. Plus, who can really hate smashing a pinata? Also, with the alternate dimension, every screen has two variations, though its not always much of a difference. Sometimes it's just water being swapped out for lava or a color swap, while other times a destroyed village is inhabited by several skeletons. 


[h1]Sound Design[/h1] 
Inspired by its Mexican theme, the instruments used for the music consists of items like trumpets, guitars, drums, and I believe the harp for some of the underworld tunes. Since you'll swap back and forth throughout the game, there's a version of the music for both dimensions, with some of the underworld interpretations being pretty creepy. Otherwise, a lot of the music is fairly bright and lively, favoring the idea of a celebration more than the skeleton army's invasion. Ah well, they died once, surely they'll do so again. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2964826018
[h1]Pros[/h1] 
🌟 White knights might complain about supposed racism, but they're just projecting. GM is awesome because it celebrates Mexican culture, not lampoons it.
🌟 I enjoyed the game's sense of humor, although I didn't need an old goat hitting on my mother. 
🌟 There's a fast-travel and mini-map system that helps players navigate around the game. 


[h1]Cons[/h1] 
❌ Due to some insta-kill obstacles, a few checkpoints can be a bit annoying. The fast-travel system also would be improved if you could move from checkpoint to checkpoint. 
❌ Sometimes, I wasn't always clear what color the shields were around enemies. I'd mix up the blue and green or yellow and white. 
❌ A faster run would have been a nice way to get around quickly, as your move-set doesn't always help with that. 


[h1]Tips[/h1]
🔍 I preferred saving my money for the more expensive upgrades, or ones I knew would be immediately helpful. For example, increasing my stamina regeneration. 
🔍 You have invincibility while grappling, but there will be times when you need to dodge attacks. When I forgot that was available, I always paid for it. 
🔍 Due to how many abilities there are to unlock, I wouldn't bother exploring too much in the early game. 


[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1] 
Give me a Metroidvania game set in the dark ages or a sci-fi landscape, and I'll likely enjoy it. However, with so many cultures and options available from our own world, it's refreshing to see something different. Wrestling isn't what would normally come to mind for a platformer, but such moves were incorporated suitably for a game like this. There's some rough spots where a quality of life change here and there would be nice, but aside from a few nuisances, I enjoyed my playthrough of GM, earning most of the achievements from getting all of the optional content. For those who have difficulty with platforming, I could see a few portions being roadblocks, so you might want to have a ringer who could join you in coop in case they're not your forte. Otherwise though, I'd recommend getting GM.

135402247.review: Guacamelee! is simply an amazing metroidvania with a Mexican setting. The art-style has a cartoonish angular look, which may look a bit weird at first, but it fits well and establishes the game identity, since it’s immediately recognizable. It has a lot of charm and humor as well. The story is basic, with the game shining in the gameplay. To be honest, it’s nothing you haven’t seen before, but it’s well implemented. The game is fun, and the controls feel right, both in combat and platforming sections. Combat is melee focused, where you combo normal attacks, throws and specials moves. A clever design choice is that these special moves are also used in movement and are needed to access some optional areas, and in true metroidvania style, some areas aren’t accessible during your first visit. The map does a great job marking those spots, so you can easily return later when you have the necessary abilities. The soundtrack is also great. Given the setting, I was afraid it was going to be very Mexican, but to my surprise, it’s way more modern and videogamey, while still being Mexican inspired. I was humming along a lot of times. It’s also a great game to hunt 100% completion. Some optional challenges can be a bit harder, but there’s nothing hardcore in here. More importantly, it doesn’t feel like a chore. The Super Turbo Championship Edition is also the definitive version of the game, with more content added. Not only that, but that content is seamlessly integrated. I only played this version, and I couldn’t tell what was the original and the new content. It was all great. And there’re also more good stuff, like 4 player co-op and a Steam Workshop for custom costumes. I had a great time with this game, and it’s an easy recommendation. Definitely worth your time and money.

135342717.review: So much to love about this game. Great combat, great platforming, cutesy story, all wrapped up in a thematic package that 100% commits to the bit. Uppercutting and suplexing and luchadoring will never get old. The platforming challenges were just difficult enough to be satisfying. The game is also super forgiving, dying doesn't yeet you back to the start and force you to replay repetitive bits. Hard mode provides a solid challenge. Right when I thought I had the combat pegged and could wipe bosses without getting hit, hard mode told me to sit down and gitgud. It wasn't agonizingly difficult, just enough to freshen up the challenge again. Guacamelee is a goat punch of charm right to the chest.

135127030.review:
En pocas palabras:

Si excluyo Hollow Knight, este Guacamelee! es el juego con el que mejor lo he pasado en los últimos tiempos. Es realmente divertido. De 11 en este sentido. Y también es el juego que he desinstalado con más rabia nada más terminarlo. Aún así es un juego sobresaliente (a pesar de la estúpida decisión de diseño tras su final), que seguro reinstalaré (o cuya segunda parte compraré) y que recomiendo por 10, 15 ó 20 euros, lo que estimes conveniente. Porque los vale.

---------------------------------------------

Lo mejor:

* Inteeeeennnsoooo!!!
* El chivo.
* La locura y la alegría general que contagia su gameplay.
* Que no deja de añadir mecánicas hasta casi el final del juego.
* La mezcla de géneros y estilos.
* El arte gráfico (le va como anillo al dedo).
* La banda sonora (y los efectos de sonido).
* El diseño de zonas, mapeado, habilidades. 
* El control del personaje, magnífico.
* Divertido a rabiar.
* Técnicamente excelente.
* Casi cualquier cosa que se diga de él.

Lo bueno:

* Todo es excelente.

Lo malo:

* Nada.

Lo peor:

* Su final. Lamentable por varios motivos.

--------------

El final de este Guacamelee! es lamentable (ojo contiene spoilers) no solo porque te escamotéa "porque si" un final bueno del juego dejándote con mal sabor de boca gratuito.. ya que tu lo has completado de manera correcta y satisfactoria. Esto ya lo hemos visto muchas veces antes y en muchos juegos. Y siempre es una mala decisión. Pero bueno. El final de Guacamelee! es lamentable, sobre todo, porque sus desarrolladores decidieron que es OBLIGATORIO conseguir ciertos objetos y superar ciertas zonas ocultas (y bien ocultas, ojo).. si quieres alcanzar un final (que no sé si será el único) aceptable del juego. Y no te lo indican en ningún momento del juego. Aunque lo hicieran, es como si Hollow Knight, para "sentir que lo has terminado", cuidado, te OBLIGARA a superar sus zonas opcionales, como el Sendero del Dolor. Esto es un sinsentido y una decisión de diseño ESTÚPIDA en un juego, que por lo demás, es redondo. De 11 sobre 10. Y esto es lo que te hace enfadar de verdad: "¿por qué estropear ASÍ un juego tan bueno?"

134260849.review:
Time for a real review for this game.  Is it fun?  Yes.  Is it Well made?  Absolutely.  Is it hard?  Let's put it this way.  Checking the achievements - which you get some of for standard actions such as completing boss fights or areas - only 40% of all people playing this game have made it past the first boss area.  Only about 20% have made it as far as the last area, and less than that have finished the game.  These stats roughly apply to both this version and the gold version.  So, all these reviews saying the game is easy to average difficulty - no it isn't.  Not even remotely.  This is pro level stuff.

Expect to die.  A lot.  And I mean a LOT.  Expect to find many areas where your average player will just give up and quit playing from sheer frustration or genuine lack of knowing how to proceed.  Which is a shame, because it really is fun and well made.  And it is generous with power ups.  But it's hard.  Very.  Only masochists, people with endless patience, or pro level platform gamers need apply.

Do I recommend it?  Yes.  Just know the truth of what you are getting yourself into.   The one thing I will say helps is that it is sometimes forgiving where you continue from when you die, and it's not a game over kind of death, just a teleport back to the last save altar if you die from damage (with whatever fight scenario you were in respawned), or last ledge you happened to be standing on if you die from falling.  Don't mistake me saying that for oh so it is easy.  It's not.  Again, only 40% of all people playing this game even made it past the first boss area.

+ Most of the jumping puzzles are decent.

CONS:
- Tedious combat.

VERDICT:
Guacmelee! Is a mediocre Metroidvanina, there's plenty of other games that do this better, which may put some players on the fence about this game, such as myself. It hasn't got many downsides but the gameplay tends to play it safe with the combat, which to me, is a very important part to this type of game.

They did a fantastic job with the jumping puzzles, this is where I think the main enjoyment is at and it's very rewarding when you complete the puzzle. The next thing that should be mentioned would be the artwork, it's so colourful and vibrant that it kept me interested for a while.

Overall Guacamelee! Does deserve to be played but know that other games do this a lot better, getting it on a sale would be the wisest move.
Total Score = 58/100.

GAMEPLAY:
Guacamelee! is a hybrid 2D Metroidvania style action platform and brawler. Players control the luchador Juan and explore an open, non-linear world to complete the central story objectives while collecting necessary character upgrades and battling enemies. Coins collected from defeated enemies are used to buy new skills at shops, which also double as checkpoints. The game features drop-in co-op play, with the second player assuming the role of Tostada, Guardian of the Mask.

133386911.review: Enjoyable metroidvania with a twist. Lots of humor and some great platforming. The fighting combosystem is quite extensive and hard to execute on, so lots of training is recommended. On normal, most enemies are manageable using a small combo set.

133220584.review: Guacamelee is a fun game. Its metroidvania aspect is really streamlined so there isn't much exploration to really be had so if you're looking for that this might not be quite what you're looking for. However, once you get past its slow startup and you unlock most of your moves the beat em up part of the game becomes really fun and satisfying. It also has a lot of charm, humor, and is chock full of references to classic indie games. Overall it was a good experience and I'd say if you're considering it, it's worth picking up.

133124276.review:
This Metroidvania is goofy in the best possible way. I personally love the style of the game, but I think if you're sensitive to cultural appropriation you might dislike this game.

The platforming is pretty great, but its the interesting combat system that really sets it apart. It's based around making combos by throwing enemies into one another, uppercutting them into the air,  and keep hitting them in the air to keep the combos rolling.

My main gripe with the game is its inconsistent difficulty curve. It's boringly difficult during the first half or so, allowing you to pretty much turn your brain off and faceroll the fights. It doesn’t really motivate the player to explore the move sets. Enemies die so quickly there isn't even that much opportunity to practice, even if you're looking to. During the later stages of the game suddenly the difficulty jumps up hardcore. I actually think this makes for a better game, but it's quite a jarring transition.

You might start this game off by thinking it's a fun little platformer fighter to unwind with, but suddenly you're forced to become serious and have to completely change the attitude with which you play. 

The game would be far better if the difficulty gradually ramped up between 5% and 75% of the game

132882437.review: Guacamelee 1 is a classic metroidvania. Far more linear than some of its peers, but trading that off for some of the best combat in the genre. With tight gameplay wrapped up in a very unique aesthetic which pays homage to Mexican culture, it's an easy recommendation.

132649660.review:
Disclaimer: I don't usually play metroidvanias or platformers, but I can sometimes enjoy them
... so you can assume I didn't like Guacamelee as much as I wish I did.

I expected something funny. The game name is pun! There's posters that reference other games and overly festive music every time you learn a new ability. And yet, plot cutscenes don't even contain an ounce of humor.

I expected something fun to play. Fighting enemies at the start was fun; trying to aim for a higher combo by throwing the enemies around and all. But by the end of the game, I felt like combat arenas were just mindless enemy spam, and although I got new abilities, I was worse at fighting them off.

There's also a difficulty spike where the game suddenly expects you to complete really long screens that include platforming and combat without dying in lava. Because falling into lava or running into blades kills you and respawns you at the last checkpoint, but falling into poison or falling into the void teleports you back to the last platform. You go from being able to retry the last jump you missed, to having to do harder platforming without failing once.

Similarly, there's that one screen where you need to do dodge, double jump, air dash, switch dimensions and up-B in a very short amount of time. It's the only instances where the game asks you to do that; and no it wasn't in a sequence of levels with increasing difficulty, it just happened to be there. Also, there's two autoscrolling tower levels. That's one too many.

Other annoying points were that the controls were too tight for me (the up button *must* be pressed before B or the ability doesn't activate) and that the final boss is different from all the other fights: [spoiler] it's more of a puzzle where you need to figure out what you're supposed to do, while all the other boss fights were hitting the boss until it died[/spoiler].

For a game that I expected to make me smile, I ended up feeling frustratingly weak. It feels like a very well-polished student game that's just not that interesting in the end.

TL;DR I know I'm not good at this kind of game, but the difficulty spike is awful

132538762.review:
I can't possibly say no harder to a game than this one. It takes every lesson from prior titles, and iterates on all of the worst aspects, while removing anything good. This process is done, as they constantly reference other, better media, reminding you of precisely how bad this game actually is. 

I think the worst aspect of this, is that you don't truly understand how bad it is until you can no longer return it, as it unfurls into some twisted lovechild of the worst metroid puzzles, and pieces of actual, factual, Kaizo trash.

The game's incredibly slow controls and sluggish response time feels more at home in a souls title, but enemies there move at compensatory speeds; unlike this title.

The boss that finally killed this for me was (I believe) the second boss, the angry lady along with the design of everything between her and (the genius tbh) small hole upgrade.

Any room and space I entered I could hear myself asking "Would it be possible to make this room more infuriating than it is right now?" the answer was always no.

her design was so annoying and opaque with endless frustration exponentially compounding with every phase that I genuinely wanted to break my controller. The final phase, which I assume was built to make you use the previously introduced shield mechanics, requires RNG to ensure both are in a vulnerability phase at the same time, near enough to hit, reachable, and with you not in some 2 second long knock back, or in the middle of doing literally anything.

I should have tapped out at the Bowser boss in temple 1. I should have realized the Kaizo DNA present. Especially with the variety of slowing mechanics that were layered atop a boss where you would be given almost no time to escape from.

I spent most of my play time unable to control my character, or waiting for my character to get back up after some random thing happened. 

Further; floaty platforming controls, without a reliable double jump, on platforms barely wide enough to have hit detection, right at a timed switch... Right outta mario maker's worst.

I'd love a refund; especially since it would have taken a substantial amount of effort to make a product this fantastically bad.

132291514.review:
I will start off by stating that I don't typically enjoy metroidvanias but this game was one of the exceptions. 

Gameplay:
Truly wonderful! Very addicting! Action-packed! This game gives you a range of abilities and combos that seems overwhelming as every single button on the Xbox controller does a different attack/move but you adjust to it and I would say it is easy to catch on. 

Atmosphere:
This is really where the designers nailed it. The design is absolutely stunning and really gives off what Mexico would look like in a video game. Many cultural references were nailed beautifully in this game. The catchy music, bright visuals, and character designs are well done, to say the least. The designers were clearly passionate about this game and it is easy to see.  

Storyline:
This is actually where the game is weakest. The story is pretty bland, very much of a Super Mario game in which you have to go save the princess type of thing. In fact, there was a couple of Mario references in the game which I thought was hilarious (also a reference to Metroid so these designers love Nintendo). There is an ending and an alternative ending...but the amount of work you have to do for the alternative ending for what you receive...not really worth it. You could beat the game and then watch the other ending online without the hassle. You gain only one extra ability if you wish to continue playing and collecting orbs which you will pretty much only use to break purple barriers. I expected a new suit or at least something other than just a new slideshow for going to the extra mile. 

Price:
It's worth it! However, it's an older game so you may as well wait for it to be on sale if you waited to this point.

Conclusion:
There is a reason this is a well-known indie title. The design and gameplay push this game to be one of the best metroidvanias I have played in a long time. This game can beat around 8 hours which is the perfect time frame in my opinion (10 hours if you want the alternative ending). If you want to give a friend a game, this is a great present for Cinco De Mayo. 

Score:
8/10

131476604.review:
Este juego es un metroidvania basado en la cultura mexicana que tiene bastante carácter, por un lado, tiene, en su mayoría, un diseño de escenarios espectacular. Las ciudades son preciosas y están cuidadas hasta el más mínimo detalle. En un goce visual. Por otra parte, tiene un combate bastante entretenido y conforme avanzas en la historia puedes hacer más convos, a la vez que aparecen nuevos enemigos con distintas debilidades. En este sentido el combate es muy entretenido. El apartado musical también está muy bien conseguido, tiene canciones populares que conjuntan perfectamente con las ciudades. Conforme avanzas, no todo es pelear, hay partes de la historia donde tienes que hacer parkour y utilizar tus habilidades para continuar. Tiene unas cuantas misiones secundarias que son bastante entretenidas pero son cortas. También, hay lugares donde puedes probar tus habilidades haciendo desafíos. La historia está bien y los personajes tienen bastante carisma. El problema que yo encuentro es que, en el nivel final, empieza a empeorar visualmente y es muy tedioso. También que los bosses son bastante faciles, tiene un modo dificil pero no lo he probado. Aunque si quieres que sea un reto puedes ponerte el traje de piñata y sufrir. (Se pueden comprar mejoras y trajes con el dinero del juego). 

El juego en sí, dura unas 9 horas yendo con tranquilidad y completando algunos lugares al 100%. Para completar el 100% supongo que son unas 20 horas aproximadamente. Con todo esto, recomiendo el juego porque es bastante bueno y no dudes en probarlo si lo tienes gratis. Si tienes pensado comprarlo te diría que lo puedes comprar perfectamente al precio al que está, aunque si no tienes prisa, puedes esperar a las rebajas. También tiene multijugador local de hasta 4 jugadores. Por último, hay otra versión del juego pero esta es más completa. 
Overall: 7.5/10

129652682.review:
Guacamelee is a solid title, and is a game definitely worth playing through. With good gameplay, good atmosphere, and good music; this cross between a metroidvania platformer and a beat'em up combo fighter is both satisfying and fun.

Grapple an enemy and kick them into a group for a big knockdown. Grab hold of a flying chupacabra and piledrive it into the earth. Dash punch into an uppercut and headbutt enemies into smithereens. The combat is pure fun, and isn't all that hard (bosses can be tough), even on hard mode.

The platforming is where the challenge lies, especially in the optional sections like Tule Treetops and Cueva de la Locura. These two lategame sections are unbelievably tough but are actually really satisfying to beat. Although you [i]do[/i] have to beat them for the alternate, and in my opinion, more satisfying, ending.

This is a game you've probably heard of, but maybe never actually seen gameplay of. It's done crossovers with everything from Brawlout to Dead Cells. Its reputation preceeds it, and for good reason.

I turned myself into a chicken. Funniest shit I've ever seen.

128530080.review:
Between the gameplay, the visual presentation, the always-upbeat soundtrack and the characters, it's clear Guacamelee's main objective is for you to have as much silly fun as possible

There's no greater philosophical themes, or finger-breaking difficulty for difficulty's sake; Just a charming, vibrant adventure oozing with love for Mexican culture and the Metroidvania sub-genre

Beating up hoards of skeletons, while jamming out with the ever-cheerful OST, puts you in a zen mode I can't quite explain, it's a sort of "relaxed excitement"

----------------------------------------------------------------

As for some notable flaws:

- Despite being a Metroidvania, the game is oddly linear, your next destination is always clearly defined and there is always only one area you're really meant to be exploring at any given time; the world doesn't quite feel like a real place the hero is traversing, with choices and branching paths, but just a video game map, which is fine for Guacamelee's size and fun-centric design, but noticeable enough

- Hard mode; It's pretty much just normal mode, except all the enemies have more health, and deal more damage,  which results in a second playthrough that just seems... slower and duller, as every foe gets an artificial boost - you'll be executing the same combos over and over and over while the baddies' healthbars barely budge, it simply gets boring compared to the fast paced normal mode

- This is a pretty personal nitpick, but I believe text boxes are a very overlooked part of a game's aesthetic; A good text box can add so much personality and flair to the characters and the game as a whole - take Celeste's text box for example! A sleek, textured backdrop displaying a beautiful, hand-drawn, 2D animation of the currently speaking character, while adorable gibberish mimicking human speech plays over every rapidly appearing letter, it's so fun! Guacamelee, despite having so much personality otherwise, really drops the ball in the text box department, giving us little more than a solid-color shape with no animation, and a single, mediocre sound effect, maybe I'm weird, but it is honestly the worst part of the game for me

----------------------------------------------------------------

At any rate, don't let the fact that the cons section is the longest part of this review fool you!
Guacamelee is overall a delight to play through and complete

If you're a fan of goofy, energetic escapades, that don't take themselves too seriously and are just laughs all the way through, definitely give Guacamelee a shot!

Guacamelee is a pretty fun metroidvania. The idea of your standard upgrades being combat moves was wonderful as is the combat. The art style and mexican themes are quite charming. Most of the game is running through corridors and fighting enemies in an arena but it's broken up by really fun platforming sections. The one thing I didn't like about this game but gave me a sense of nostalgia are the very dated video game references that remind me of the old days of the internet/youtube.

My play time is around 11 hours but I play this on my steam deck without setting up cloud saves first so the 4 hours is NOT my actual play time.

This game is very very short. You unlock abilities very often, and none of them feel nearly explored enough. For a metroid-vania game, i'm left with a strong unresolved feeling after finishing the main story. To my disappointment, you cant play as the woman luchador in a 1-player game.

The final boss is designed poorly. Throwing out random attacks without showing super short (specific-to-each-attack) warning animations, if at all (this is also present in a few other normal enemies), and doesn't give the player enough time to discern which movement/dodge options you have to handle each attack. And the laser attacks have annoying hitboxes that extend wider than they look.

If the game is on sale, then maybe give it a try. I don't think this is something i'd ever want to play a second time. Oh also the game has a lot of references to other games if you're into that

120761029.review:
Mola como han hecho lo de viajar entre el mundo de los vivos y el de los muertos.

Reconozco que solo por la temática mexicana ya me tenían casi convencido (la banda sonora es genial) Luego al jugarlo he visto que además de ser bonito artísticamente también es pura calidad en el resto de apartados.

Los gráficos y diseño me flipan porque recuerdan a la serie de animación Samurai Jack (2001) Luego está la jugabilidad con diferentes técnicas para hacer combos a los monstruos, si aprendes a hacerlo bien no les dejarás ni respirar.

Aunque se podría considerar un "metroidvania" por su exploración del mapa, conseguir mejoras, etc. va muchísimo más directo al grano que otros juegos de este género que suelen tener un sistema muchísimo más complejo.
Por ejemplo no tienes armas ni equipo, vas a tortazo limpio aunque puedes comprar diferentes trajes de lucha libre con habilidades pasivas. Además de la historia principal hay misiones secundarias, secretos escondidos y hasta distintos finales.

Tiene más dosis de plataformeo de lo habitual en este tipo de juegos, cosa que a mí me ha gustado mucho, pero lo comento igualmente como dato relevante.
Muy buen videojuego, lo recomiendo.

Esta ha sido mi reseña y al que no le guste que le den. 8/10

120403799.review:
Recomendable no, ¡¡HIPERRECOMENDABLE!! Como cosas positivas a destacar: la ambientación rollo mexicano, su traducción a español (que no sé si es traducción o V. O., pero es MAGNÍFICA), sus miles de referencias a otros juegos como Metroid sobre todo, el modo de animación e ilustración del juego que es espectacular visualmente y los cientos de huevos de pascua y referencias a otros juegos con traducciones literales en español que se pueden ver a lo largo de los mapas del juego.

El único contra que le podría sacar es que no sea más largo el juego y que por desgracia no tiene un «posgame» digno, pero es algo común en los juegos de esta categoría, la batalla contra el jefe final es el desenlace y no hay nada más allá después de ella. Pero está compensado por sus dos finales que aumentan la durabilidad del juego un buen cacho.

Es un 10/10, un juego de los que hace tiempo que no disfrutaba, enganchándome como cuando tenía 12 años.

P.D.: Recomiendo pasar por la Workshop y echar un vistazo a los trajes personalizados, hay uno de Samus Aran que es fabuloso, y también otros tantos de personajes famosos de otros videojuegos que te brindarán una experiencia de juego espectacular.

120327138.review:
A simple but well-done Metroidvania. With charming graphics and and a nice soundtrack, the Mexican Luchador theme exudes all of it charisma through the screen, short npc text lines and straightforward story. The combat is responsive, fluid and quite entertaining. The combo possibilities are quite varied considering you have only two buttons. The special moves are colorful and remain useful and powerful through the whole game. The enemies variety and mechanics keep you entertained with the combat and challenges all the way through, with that said, this game is on the easier side, very few battles, be it with bosses or regular enemies, will prove much of a challenge to most.

One bad thing this game have is the lack of a sidequest tracker. While said sidequest aren't long or complicated to the point of escaping from your memory, it can get bothersome to remember where you stopped at with certain quests between longer breaks.

All in all, a good game, grab it if you have the spare cash. Plus there is coop up to 4 people. 
7/10

120177099.review:
[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- It's hard to find a good place to start when every aspect of the presentation is so good
- The style of the both characters and environments is fantastic. I particularly like the villains
- The music is so good. Almost every song is a banger

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- The story is your basic "save the princess" archetype, but it's effective here because of all the level design. Going through the diverse towns and environments with NPCs directing you and cheering you on gives you a sense of progression
- With all the humor and bright colors, the game is very inviting. Those aspects make you want to keep playing it, if that makes sense
- The humor deserves special attention. There's some clever writing in here (i.e., Fray Ayayay)
- All of these factors contribute to what feels like a cohesive, well-crafted world to play around in

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- The attention paid to the other aspects of the game should clue you in to how good the gameplay is. It's outstanding
- This is much better on a controller. I found myself naturally fighting with the d-pad and platforming with the analog stick
- The fighting mechanics are quite good. By the time you pick up all the skills and abilities, fighting feels like you're playing Smash Brothers with additional platforming options
- Being a 2D platformer in the Metroid vein, a lot of those skills you pick will also help you solve platforming challenges and reach previously inaccessible areas
- Some of those puzzles are really quite challenging, and fit in well with the excellent level design
- I absolutely want to pick this one back up for a 100% run someday. It's all good enough to reexperience

[b]Overall Impressions & Performance[/b]
- This game is just pure fun. I had such a great time playing it
- Everything ran beautifully and bug-free

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]10/10[/b]. In the 2D platforming genre (including so-called "metroidvanias"), this stands at the top with games like Super Mario Bros. It's a masterpiece. I'd recommend it without reservation

Bei diesem Spiel wünschte ich mir echt ein richtig Bewertungssystem... Meine Güte frustriert dieses Spiel zum Teil enorm! Ab ungefähr 1/2 - 2/3 des Spiels wirst du fast nur noch in Instadeath-Arenen geschmissen die jeden noch so kleinen Fehltritt direkt mit dem Tod bestrafen. Wozu hat man dann überhaupt ein Lebensbalken, wenn jeder Hit quasi dein Tod bedeutet? Entweder, weil du danebengesprungen bist/ geschlagen hast oder weil dich ein Gegner trifft und du deshalb in die Instadeath-Trap fällst. Ich finde die Kämpfe so wie sie sind schon mehr als knackig genug: Ständig zwischen den Ebenen wechseln, den Überblick über die Schilde nicht verlieren und gleichzeitig den Gegnerischen Angriffen ausweichen (teilweise auch 10 oder 12 Stück auf einmal. Aber wie gesagt, das reicht noch nicht, es muss NOCHMAL schwerer werden und mit jeder Arena die du machst denkst du, viel krasser als das wird es kaum werden und du bist getäuscht. Aber anders als bei guten Soulslike Spielen ist finde ich hier der Frustfaktor immens viel höher!

118878691.review:
Are you're looking for a Metroidvania, but you're tired of aliens, anime, and dark, depressing games that take themselves too seriously? If so, then it's time to play Guacamelee. 

I'd give it a solid B. It's neat that combat abilities also serve as mobility enhancements. So the uppercut is also a super-jump, etc. The world is very colorful and detailed, but probably too slick. I think it would be more charming if it had less polish. There's also WAY too much going on in the background. You can see this in the screenshots. It kind of blurs all the areas together in my memory. 

My biggest complaint is that when you get hit, it takes too long for you to get back up. You have i-frames, but the animation slows everything down and makes the combat feel water-logged.

Overall, a genuinely funny and unique Metroidvania for when you need something different.

118774818.review:
Guacamelee is pretty much the perfect game to introduce people to not only the metroidvania genre itself, but just gaming in general. This game overall is fun, simple and not hard, although some sections spike the difficulty like the last rival fight. But besides that, it perfectly mashes the genre with the mexican culture of Lucha Libre in such a way that Mucha Lucha would be damn proud. 

This is the best version to play as it also has Co-Op on top of some little extra things the Original and Gold don't have. If you have your doubts, buy it on sale. It won't disappoint.

116353140.review:
Un juego entretenido, con buenas mecánicas y un buen desarrollo de habilidades. Sin embargo, se queda en ello, un plataformero exigente que te pone a prueba, pero que no quedará grabado en tu memoria como un juego memorable y digno por conseguir. ¿Quieres un reto y pasarlo bien mientras juegas? Cómpralo sin duda. ¿Quieres un juego que trascienda y rompa los esquemas de los plataformeros? Quizá hay mejores opciones en el mercado. 

_____________________________________________________________________________________

A pesar del trabajo que conllevó la construcción del juego y los diferentes escenarios, en ocasiones esta misma construcción hace que no se sienta inmersivo. Es decir, las misiones y mecánicas dan una sensación de “‘ve al punto A’, ‘oh, ya fuiste y aprendiste una nueva técnica, es momento de que vayas al punto B’”, y así sucesivamente durante gran parte de la trama del juego (por no decir toda, ya que para el 100% sí hace necesaria la exploración autónoma). Esto le quita atractivo, ya que, por sus dinámicas, y hasta cierto punto su dificultad, tenía todo por delante para convertirse en un juego que te llama, engancha y te exige jugarlo. 

Personalmente siento que esto es producto de una historia más bien floja, utilizando el típico recurso de la damisela en peligro y el pobre enamorado que debe convertirse en alguien lo suficientemente fuerte como para afrontar el peligro y rescatar a la doncella de las garras del mal. Esto conlleva a que el juego pase sin pena ni gloria en cuanto a trama se refiere. Un ejemplo de este apartado podría ser el personaje femenino, al que uno accede por medio de la máscara. A pesar de que uno la utilice en todo momento, y juegue con el ‘personaje femenino’ (que lo único que varía es la skin, más no la jugabilidad, ya que es idéntica) durante el desarrollo de la historia se hace evidente que uno continúa jugando con Juan, nuestro héroe primario. Esto le quita seriedad y razón de ser a las skins entre masculino y femenino, ya que siempre el protagonista es el masculino. Si quisieron implementar el personaje femenino debieron darle el protagonismo que merecía, de resto me parece simplemente una pérdida de esfuerzo por parte de los creadores del juego. 

Quizá una respuesta a este fallo en la trama podría atribuírsele a que es un juego independiente, y que por tanto no posee los mismos recursos que un triple A del cual se espera que sea lo mejor y lo más esperado. Si bien esta podría ser una razón, siento que sería brindar excusas a esta falencia que posee. El hecho de que sea independiente no implica que tenga que ser lo mínimo. Al contrario, como la creación del juego requiere de un esfuerzo gigantesco para poderlo publicar y comercializar, se hace necesario que se pula hasta los mínimos detalles con el fin poder continuar con secuelas. Aunque, puesto que existe Guacamelee 2, parece que sí cumplieron los mínimos y eso representó esos frutos. Espero puedan continuar mejorando. 

Un aspecto en el que sí resalta y que lo hace un juego llamativo e interesante es la dificultad. El juego es accesible para cualquier persona acostumbrada a jugar juegos de plataforma (tipo Super Mario Bros), y gradualmente comienza a hacerse exigente en algunos apartados. Ahora, si eres una persona completista, que busca encontrar cada opción que te permite el juego, buscar todos los secretos y llegar a cada lugar disponible, en otras palabras, completar los logros y llegar al tan anhelado 100%, tienes un excelente desafío por delante. Los apartados de los retos del Infierno ponen a prueba de ensayo y error, concentración y precisión a cualquiera que lo intente. Fenomenal, excelente punto para el juego.

Los enemigos son variaciones de uno mismo: los esqueletos. Estos son los que conforman el ejército de Calaca (enemigo a derrotar). Una idea base y acorde con la trama del juego son los esqueletos, los cuales se relacionan fácilmente con la muerte. Además, las diferentes formas en que se presentan, así como la manera en que hay que derrotarlos, hacen que sea una idea sencilla pero bien desarrollada. Así es como debe ser. Quizá uno esperaría gran variación de enemigos, pero la forma en que presentan a los diferentes esqueletos responde a lo que uno demanda en cuestión de adversarios. Este aspecto de los enemigos, también se relaciona con la mecánica del cambio de las dimensiones, la cual se utiliza en su justa medida, incrementando la dificultad y forzando la práctica con el fin de pulir y ser preciso a ala hora de utilizar alguna habilidad y/o golpe. Excelente. 

En lo personal el mejor plataformero que he probado es Hollow Knigth. Pero siento que este último no hubiese sido posible sin la existencia de Guacamelee. Los de Hollow identificaron, explotaron y desarrollaron ese talón de Aquiles que tuvo Gucamalee y crearon uno de los mejores juegos que he podido conocer.  

Pdta: Reseña realizada después de jugar un total de 29 horas según Steam, y luego de haber completado la totalidad de los logros. Que buen desafío.

116330261.review:
[h1]My Thoughts[/h1]
One day I opened up Steam and I saw a new game that I hadn't bought. That game was Guacamelee. I was kinda surprised and saw that others also got it for free. Now I didn't have any interest in this type of game so I didn't play it for years. But now I have finally come around to it.

Overall the game isn't half bad but not great either. It doesn't have that many outright flaws, it's just that it doesn't do anything special to make it stick out from other Metroidvania's.

[h2]Story[/h2]
Story-wise the game isn't good at all, it rushes the player towards a plot point. None of the characters are interesting.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
The combat quickly wears off its charm, for me at least, it's a bit too simple and easy, there's no real challenge in combat arenas until they start throwing some instadeath mechanics in the mix, which are more frustrating than anything else. Also, the combos, there's pretty much one combo, there's going to be a new ability here and there but not change much in terms of combos. 

Boss fights are pretty good, I loved the one against 'The Terrible Trio', it felt very unique and fun to play. It's just there are barely any of them here, there are 5 in total and 2 of those are so bland and forgettable.

The controls are kinda clunky. Especially the later areas are sort of frustrating because of this, all the special moves are bound to 1 button, the only difference is the input of the analog stick. Now, this is way too easy to miss input since a thumbstick isn't the most accurate thing there is. Platforming suffers heavily under this, again at least for me. In the later areas, you have to quickly switch between worlds, use specials, et cetera. So this was rather frustrating than rewarding.

[h2]Sound[/h2]
The audio is decent, hits feel rewarding, and so on. The music is alright, it repeats the same handful of tracks over and over which eventually gets tiring, but at the start, it's quite charming, except for one track that sounds like it's made by some mentally defective child.

[h2]Visuals[/h2]
Visually the game looks good, as you can see by the screenshots. It has its charm but, again, it wears off after a while. Enemies do look unique throughout the game.

There's one major complaint I have with the visuals and that is the top bar. When playing solo there's no reason to constantly see "Press > to join" times 3. It just looks ugly and obnoxious.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
All in all, it isn't a bad game, not even close. But the thing that stops me from recommending it is that it's very bland and quickly wears off the charm it has going for it. Combat gets stale fast, the story isn't interesting in the least, and the soundtrack or visuals aren't strong enough to carry it. 
I don't want to say you can't enjoy this game, it's just that I didn't enjoy it enough to give it a recommendation.
[h3]Rating[/h3]
4,5/10

116073066.review: I don't know if I and so many others had lower standards when Guacamelee originally launched or something changed in some updates, but I have never been more frustrated with the controls and overall design in a game in my life. A lot of the "skill" involved in this game involves platform puzzles that requires split second switching between dodging, double jumping and special moves. the problem is that all the specials are assigned to one button and a directional which is way too easy to  mis-input, their not quite responsive enough, and to top it all off I can't even remap the controls. So what happens is that you end up doing the same room for hours (or at times feels like it) knowing full well what needs to be done but not being able to because you're wrestling with the controls. That's just bad design.

115769485.review:
It's a game i wanted to like but it has too many issues that end up pilling on top of each other ultimately making the game a slog to play.

It's supposed to be a "metroidvania" style game but its overall designed in a way much more akin to a linear action game. Which is frustrating for me, someone who doesn't like metroidvanias, because i would much prefer that the developers made a linear action game instead. I ended up just rushing to the end without doing any optional content or side quests. It took me about 4 hours to finish the game.

There are too many platforming elements. They are tedious and it gets bogged down with gimmick after gimmick. The combat is more enjoyable and it would've been preferable if that was the focus of the game.

The combat starts out OK, but it also gets bogged down with gimmicks very quickly. By the end of the game, the player is forced to use about half a dozen different skills and abilities to even damage enemies. It doesn't make the combat challenging or varied, it just turns the whole thing into an unfun, overly complicated slog.

There's little story in the game and infrequent cutscenes (unskippable). However, the small amount of story and cutscenes that are in the game are quite terrible. Would've preferred that there was zero dialogue and the story was told through animations. The developers, in particular, have a terrible sense of humor.

The difficulty is all over the place. The game for the most part is quite easy, but every once in a while the player comes across certain rooms of platforming or combat that are just backbreaking hard.

The final boss is awful. Impressively terrible.

114210649.review:
It's....okay. I think this game is like, the perfect candidate for a "Maybe" recommendation tag on Steam. I've bought both this and the older Gold Edition and probably have 20 hours as a whole across them both and I've bounced off them each time. 

The core gameplay is fun: grappling and throwing enemies around, including into other enemies is a neat twist on the usual combat for these kinds of games. The graphics are colorful and vibrant. The music is catchy. It's not terribly long or the sort of game that pads out its runtime. Some of the dialogue can be funny. 

It's also the sort of game that trades story for gaming references and jokes that are kind of run into the ground like an episode of Family Guy. I would've appreciated a little more story or worldbuilding for as colorful as the world is, it's mostly a vehicle to give "hey I recognize that thing"-style references to other video games. This doesn't always have to be a dealbreaker, but in a Metroidvania you should want to explore the world because that's a big part of the genre's concept and Guacamelee's world isn't...interesting enough on its own to want to explore. 

It's also kind of exhausting to play: by the end, the final dungeon, once all the mechanics are unlocked, enemies have a laundry list of things you have to do to be able to kill them (gotta be in the right dimension, gotta attack them with the right color attack, gotta dodge X and Y attack, but you can't dodge Z, etc) and the fights themselves turn into chaotic clusterfucks once 3+ enemies are on the screen where the action can be difficulty to follow and I just wasn't having much fun with the core combat anymore. The mechanics seem to build on in a way that's there to make it harder to kill enemies rather than to create any kind of fun variations on the core combat loop, such as giving them the ability to teleport away from you mid-combo to break up your all-important combo stack or the ability to be immune to all damage except certain attacks. 

And then little problems like some really questionable hit detection or a boss bugging out and changing attacks mid-animation, etc.

It's also a really platforming-heavy game with some puzzles that require precise timing and a section midway through the game (the volcano) where they throw in a lot of instant-death mechanics that just...grate.

So...it's a "maybe" game. Maybe it can be a game you really dig, if the above doesn't really bother you. I'd wait for it to go on sale.

113915895.review:
A love letter to Metroid/Castlevania and 2D platformers of the past while being incredibly unique at the same time. Rather than shooting or whipping, Guacamelee feels like a beat 'em in a Metroidvania world. The attacks and combos feel incredibly natural and intuitive and when thing get chaotic, it's great fun suplexing and piledriving enemies into each other.

In addition to the combat, there is some challenging platforming but I never thought it was unfair. The controls are tight, response and if you made a mistake, it's your fault.

I absolutely love the story and the humor of the game. While other games like this feel a little forced in humor, and dialogue, you'll find yourself chuckling to the smallest things and the entire thing just feels so charming.

I can't recommend the game enough if you into Metroidvania games and want something a little different from the genre.

113801233.review: Game looks and runs great, and this newer version has some welcome additions, but there's not nearly enough new unlocks and upgrades to level out your character to address some of the harder challenges. The big detractor from my endorsement though? The mechanics for some of the platform based challenge are borderline awful, and their increasing frequency near the final portion of the game, made this game insanely frustrating. The kind with one-hit kill traps, annoying enemies with unblockable attacks and unfun mechanics tossed in for no apparent choice other than making the challenge just straight up hard. I think this is the main problem with a lot of metroidvania style games in this vein, but the unique issue with Guacamelee is that all of the abilities require precise input. If you've ever played a fighting game for the 5th or 10th time and you're trying to nail the exact input to get a special move done, you know the pain, but the makers instead went, man what if it was that fight, plus we add a bunch of exploding guys on a countdown over a pit of instant death?

113632859.review:
This game gets too much praise. Although it's not a straight up bad game, it's not as good as people try to tell you. It gets very repetitive really fast and the game elements are not that much fun to hold your attention 'til the end of the game. The fact that the game isn't very long but still too long to be fun for it's whole playtime was very exhausting for me. From the half point on i hadn't much fun with the game and was already anticipating the end so that i can be done with it. Combat is really simple but get's only more annoying. Especially in the later areas, where you're thrown with encounter after encounter, consisting of enemies which are mostly the same but in greater numbers. Don't get me started with enemies which instant kill you if you don't kill them fast enough. Endgame enemies have the mechanic to randomly teleport away, which kinda breaks the flow of combat and doesn't do anything except wasting your time & combo.
Also there are some irritating checkpoints where you have to go through another area again just to reach the point where you died, which just wastes your time. This is in particular annoying in areas where you die instantly from environmental hazards. The game doesn't do very interesting stuff with it's metroidvania elements, you just get additional attacks for color code blocks which are destroyed by those attacks - apart from wallrun or the goat fly near the end of the game there isn't anything shaking up the gameplay, and backtracking for items which are not very rewarding isn't much fun either, also because the world isn't that interesting. There is a Teleport system, although the spots are often not in smart areas which led to me not using it for the most part.

All in all i can't say that this should at all be a metroidvania, and those element feel rather forced. Could be replaced with doors & keys, this game does nothing interesting with the formula - especially as the world doesn't change as you progress the games.
If you're looking for a metroidvania, play sth else. Because most games use the metroidvania elements in a better way.

Es un videojuego que mezcla muy bien la exploración, acción y aventura en unos escenarios fantásticos, cada combo de golpes que haces te llena de determinación.

[h1]Historia:[/h1]

Tomamos el papel de Juan una persona ordinaria que pronto dejaría de serlo para entrar a un mundo de golpes, huesos rotos y muchas tortillas, de inicio a fin podemos ver la evolución de nuestro enmascarado, así mismo el macabro cambio que esta haciendo al mundo el villano Carlos Calaca con el único propósito de cumplir su ritual para unir ambos mundos.

[h1]Destacado:[/h1]

De este juego me encanto mucho los escenarios, la banda sonora que los acompaña, el cómo varía dependiendo la dimensión en a que estes, la satisfacción enorme que genera completar el juego al 100%, los distintos trajes que puedes usar, entre otros temas alucinantes que valen  la pena.  
   
[h1]Puntos negativos:[/h1]

El único punto negativo es que tiene una ligera torpeza al momento de usar las habilidades especiales y que no se puede jugar multijugador en línea, solo se puede local.

[h1]Para Resumir:[/h1]

Es un juego que vale la pena tener en la biblioteca, puedes adaptarte a su modo de juego fácilmente, ir de prisa o disfrutar de los escenarios, personajes y enemigo, aparte de todas las diferencias ocultas que el juego tiene para ofrecernos, mientras escuchamos soundtracks como en el gran templo.

[b]Mi Puntuación Es De: 7.9/10:[/b]

Gráficos: 9/10
Historia: 10/10
Jugabilidad: 7/10
Escenarios: 10/10
Banda sonora: 10/10

[h1]!!Gracias por tomarse el tiempo de leer, un abrazo!![/h1]
