108141468.review:
Quick Description:
-I just played both Guacamelee Super Turbo Championship Edition and Guacamelee 2 back to back.  Interestingly enough, I absolutely loved the sequel but was left very divided on how I felt about the original.  The sequel expands upon everything that is introduced in the first game, and cleans up every problem area that I ran into.  It's a true labor of love, and a clear example of how an Indie team can turn a promising yet deeply flawed game into a true work of art.  Unfortunately, the first Guacamelee can't compete w/ average beat 'em ups and offers very minimal metroidvania elements, while also being very rough around the edges.  This is a shame b/c there is so much charm, humor, and love put into this game, but it just doesn't quite all come together in the end.

What's Good:
-There is a ton of creativity and charm in this title.  I can't think of another beat 'em up metroidvania that offers bright colors, Mexican folklore, and breaks the third wall w/ humor constantly.  There are a ton of bright, likeable npcs throughout the game that really add life to the world.
-One of the smartest choices that the devs made was to make most of the major mechanics act as duel functions.  The uppercut is essential in combat, but also plays a role in breaking red bricks that block pathways, and is essential in platforming and secret hunting.  The dash punch also will be used in combat, platforming, and gatekeeping.  
-The impact when punching, dodging, and slamming enemies is perfect imo.  This is another area that this game really shines.  One of the biggest disappointments of Ender Lillies was how lifeless some of the attacks and dodges felt.  When you perfectly dodge an attack, the game slightly slows down to emphasize that movement.  When you hit an enemy, you really feel the impact, which adds weight to every combo.
-The dimension swapping ability, although underutilized, has so much potential.  This is another use of duel functionality.  The dimension swapping ability allows for every biome to have two different biomes w/ unique secrets and enemies.  It also adds another layer to every platforming section and becomes a focal point of late game content.
-Secret hunters will be delighted, as there are tons!  Most of the secrets are in fairly obvious locations, but there are quite a few secrets that are very difficult to find.

Could Use Some Changes:
-The biggest complaint that I have, is that this feels like a game w/ a lot of great ideas, but they just aren't executed to their full potential.  Combat feels great, but the enemies and even bosses are so easy, that they never feel like a real threat.  You can see that this could be a really unique metroidvania, but it's just not an organic, interconnected world that gives a sense of wonder during exploration.  The chicken power is basically only used for a few secrets and some mandatory tunnels.  This game kind of reminds me of Ori and the Blind Forrest.  I saw incredible potential, but it kind of felt like an extended tech demo instead of a fully coherent game. 
-This isn't really a metroidvania.  It's a beat 'em up w/ some very light metroidvania elements sprinkled in there.  It's exceptionally linear, and the game always tells you exactly where to go.  Even if you try to go out of your way to go to a different location, you will likely run into a literal brick wall.  The world doesn't feel interconnected, it feels much closer to a stage based action platformer.
-The pacing of this game feels off.  The first 3-4 hrs are extremely slow and dull.  If you are remotely experienced in this genre, then by hr 5, you will be so overpowered b/c finding health and stamina upgrades are really easy early on.  The game starts to hit it's stride near the 7-8 hr mark, but just as that happens, the game abruptly ends.  
-This is an extremely easy game.  All of the secrets are either health or stamina which is really helpful, but very boring.  Not every game needs to be challenging, but outside of the final boss and some optional secret hunting and side quests, there are close to no real threats in this game.  You can brute force your way through pretty much everything, especially all combat situations.  The platforming is the only area that is even remotely a challenge, but even that is fairly simple the first 2/3 of the game.

Thoughts:
-So I got this game for free during a giveaway about 2 years ago.  I then went and bought the sequel for a couple of bucks, but both have sat in my backlog ever since.  I want to make it clear, that I will be giving an absolutely glowing review of Guacamelee 2 and that I highly recommend it.  However, I can't recommend this one.  There are so many average beat 'em ups that are simply better than this, and this doesn't even compete w/ middle of the road metroidvanias.  I can't think of a single thing that this game offers that the sequel doesn't expand upon in a better and more creative way.  The sequel fixes every issue that I mentioned above and feels like a truly finished project.  So, the only ppl I would feel comfortable recommending this to, are ppl that loved the sequel, but just want more Guacamelee.  I personally, would rather just play the sequel over again.

Consensus:
-Bottom Shelf Gaming (Tier 5 and makes up 10% of my reviews).  It pains me to do this, b/c clearly this is an Indie studio that deeply loves this gaming franchise and put so much love in both of these games.  This is one of the rare cases where the sequel is so much better than the original, that the original becomes a game that is hard to market to players.  I review games based on a curve and compare them to everything that I have played b/c I think it's important to evaluate whether there is another title that offers better value.

105476857.review:
This game is the perfect combination of beat'em up, metroidvania and precision platformer, and I say that as someone who sucks at precision platformers and gets easily frustrated.

The base game mechanics is platforming and fighting enemies with different moves that you unlock throughout the game.

The progression of the main story is more or less linear, but you always have to go back to previously visited areas to open new passages once you acquire new abilities that allow you to pass through them.

You might think that the beat'em up part of the game means it's going to be quite repetitive, but in reality the game offers a decent sense progression and variety by giving you new, more powerful abilities, making you face newer, stronger enemies, and presenting you with some challenges of what you would call precision platforming, that are neither too easy, not too hard, so most people will find them enjoyable.

Now, if you're not quite a fan of precision platforming, don't worry. I kinda like games like Celeste, but they seem quite difficult and frustrating to me, too. Guacamelee, however, gives you the right amount of precision platforming for those who like to casually play precision platforming, but don't like when it becomes too hard. In other words, the precision platforming elements of this game are kept to a minimum, and are well-balanced in terms of difficulty: neither so easy that would make you bored, nor so hard that would make you quit (although you might be at the brink of quitting a couple of times).

Having said that, sometimes you might get frustrated and quit it after a few attempts, but it's often the case that when you come back to the game the next time, you'll manage to do it. This has happened to me a couple of times. So my advice to you: Don't give up!

Overall, the game is real fun if you like platforming.

104261522.review:
This game is an amazing ride from start to finish. The story is kinda basic yes but even that aside, it has so much great on its corner that I can't help but recommend it

For starters, the look and feel is so obviously influenced by Mexican culture. It's just so beautiful to look at. Everything is just infused with this colorful and lively style which I really like. Fair warning tho but sometimes it may get too colorful to the point that the creators had to put an epilepsy/seizure warning for the game. 

The difficulty is just the right kind of piss me off hard that I'm looking for. I wouldn't say it's the most difficult MetroidVania I've played (Hollow Knight still holds that honor cos I can't finish it to this day huhu) but that does NOT mean it's easy. There are a lot of parts that need split-second decisions and then it does the wrong move and then you blame the controller for not reading it right! It's that kinda difficult. But still I was able to finish it. It took a few good hours of work and determination to get what I needed especially for the True/Good Ending.

The gameplay itself feels just right at home with most modern MetroidVanias in the sense that it doesn't have a levelling up system akin to CastleVania or BloodStained. Instead, it's all about getting new moves or augments to your arsenal to make you stronger. One more thing, in this edition, it has something called Intenso mode which was not available in the Gold Edition. It's a neat addition but I rarely found the use for it. It's cool and you're stronger but I feel that it drains way too quickly anyway and it's just as much a bitch to refill it. Very rarely did I use it like when enemies were too difficult for one part so it made the task easier or go faster but for the most part, it was unnecessary for me. I used it about 5 times max throughout the game. It's also probably cos the control for it is pressing down both the analog sticks. Why not use the L+R trigger instead? Maybe it's meant to deter players from using it so that they don't need to depend on it so much? But whatever, gameplay is still rock solid

Highly recommended if you just love the look of Mexican culture and a right amount of difficulty.

101303182.review:
Where to start, this game is quite simply the best platformer, metroidvania, and beat em' up mashed into one very solid title. At first I was genuinely turned off by the amount of genres mashed together considering how many other similar genre titles fall short.

The game starts off a bit slow, giving you a simple grab and 3 hit punch attack to use. Then slowly and steadily over the course of the game adds new simple moves into your movelist that slowly and steadily increase your overall power and allows you to push a combo further on a single enemy or multiple groups of enemies which are varied and allow you to continue to utilize your 3 hit combo when you'd normally be stopped.

The platforming puzzles and the map are perfectly tuned for what you need, sure at times you may be wondering where to go but know that any area without a chest is the way forward to your next objective. You could also get secrets and do side quests on your way to the end of the game but they aren't required to actually do well.

Overall this game has done phenomenally well to keep me engaged and at the edge of my seat to figure out what happens to Juan to the end and I will highly recommend this to anyone looking for a real gem of a game that hits all the right beats and utilizes it's genre mixture to the fullest.

100652554.review:
Amazing game; Guacamelee manages to achieve a near-perfect balance of challenge and accommodation.  Fall into a pit?  You instantly respawn back on your last solid ground.  Die in combat?  Savepoints are everywhere, and they heal you to full.  You almost never find yourself repeating challenges you've already beaten just so you can get another chance at what you failed at last time; instead platforming is broken up into small, tight, chunks that can be focused on, beaten, and moved on from.  Even the bosses have built-in savepoints in between phases.

As an adult with a busy life, I don't have the time, willpower, or teenage reflexes needed to do everything consistently perfect.  Being able to retry challenges until I can beat them without the frustration of long stretches of slog in between checkpoints is an absolutely wonderful design that every game like this should implement.

100614893.review:
Un juego muy divertido. Inicialmente, el control del jugador es sencillo. Según avanzas los retos y enemigos son más difíciles, pero sin llegar a ser muy complejos (hasta el momento). 99349461.review: It's a fun game. The combat isn't super technical but it is possible to chain some combos together. The platforming challenges are good but they don't really get truly challenging until the late game after you've gotten all the abilities. For a metroidvania I found it to be a bit too linear for my taste and exploration isn't that inciting since the rewards are always predictable and really just amount to stat upgrades. The soundtrack and artstyle are great. The humour is hit or miss, a lot of it is references to games and memes from the time of its release and in 2021 it feels very dated but it's never in your face and obnoxious like the Borderlands games. The length of the game is perfect, if the playtime were any longer I would've gotten bored and dropped it. If you like metroidvanias and timing-based platforming challenges it's worth a try.

Incredibly fun Metroidvania. There are still a lot of rough edges here which get cleaned up in the sequel. Its a bit shaky In terms of level design, enemy design, map design, and especially progression. It sometimes feels like the developers didn't properly know how to deal with a certain part or how to make certain sections more engaging. Thats why this game constantly jumps between really fun and fantastic to sort of ok. Especially the early sections can feel really slow and simplistic for a game like this. 

But at its core its still a fantastic game with a really unique setting (Middle and South American culture are incredibly underrated in the gaming industry) and a lot of personality to stand on its own. If anything its great to play this and then play the sequel just to see how many improvements were made. I would still heavily recommend this game even without the sequel, it does not need a sale at all to sell itself. I would even say that this game is worth more then the starting asking price.

96049746.review:
TL:DR; frustrating, not fun, platforming sessions are so badly designed it is only a matter of time you will drop this out of frustration. Avoid at all costs. 

Full review: this was one of the most frustrating experience at playing a game ever. Art is good, combat is reasonably good, could have been a fun game, but game-design is among the worst imaginable when it comes to the platforming sessions, and there's no way to avoid them. Part of the problem is that every ten minutes, a new control key or key combination is added, and soon they exceed the number of fingers or appendages of any human. Key combinations are particulary bad as the order in which you press the keys matter, and is not responsive, so at best you get them once every three attempts.

But the biggest problem are the unreasonable, unavoidable platforming sessions. Navigating across platform can be a bliss in other games, in this one is just a pain. For some reasohs, they decided that it would be fun to force the player do a predefined robotic sequence of too many actions. Thet stops being any fun quite soon, and becomes just a challenge of patience. You'll have to alternate between 50 different moves in a quick unforgiving succession. There is no joy in failing 1000 times, or in succeeding alike. 

It boils down to a matter of pressing the right action in tight sequences, so it basically feels like a Hasbro Simon electronic toy game for brain dead people, only instead of being 4 buttons there is like 20 and sequences are way, way too long. How on earth they could image this could be considered even remotely fun to play. You want to see the rest of the game you paid good money for, so you try with patience to surpass a section or two, or ten, or twenty, hoping they will stop the nonsense and let you play the game, but no, it gets worse and worse until it stops being worth it. There is one point, for example, where to progress you need to jump swap-plane jump, jump, double jump, swap "plane" twice, dodge, upper cut, side smash, append to wall, double jump.... the list goes on it basically never ends, one key out of sequence and you are out, one millisecond away and you have to redo it all. Of course, there is not way to avoid that sequence. I dunno what to say, it is the opposite of fun. 

I see positive reviews but I'm guessing they wrote them before ever getting this late in the game. At the beginning, nothing makes you suspect levels will be so poorly designed later. 

I finished the metroidvanias that are considered the hardest ones on the market, but I never encountered this level of frustration. 

Vote 2/10.

Guacamelee is a quirky & fun, light-hearted metrodvania set in colorful Mexican cartoon theme.

I would say this is a pretty *EASY* game (even on the unlockable "Hard" mode), since there's literally no penalty whatsoever on death, and the monsters weren't really challenging to beat at all once you got the hang of the combat (There are some aspects of platformer that's rather frustrating though, if you intend to complete every side contents for the achievements [spoiler]and to unlock the alternate, good ending[/spoiler]).

Speaking of the combat, it was fast-paced and fluid, not deep but still pretty fun to play, smashing those skellies with funny wrestling moves and combo are somewhat hilarious and satisfying.

Overall I would say in no way this is a bad game, so it's easy to recommend 👍.
Oh and on a side note, there are A TON of funny easter eggs that took references from many other games & memes to be found, Metroid, Super Mario, FEZ, Journey, to name a few... Was pleasant to discover if you recognize them~

95002664.review:
Had been watching some top ten metroidvania videos in an effort to find some more games in the genre worth adding to my wishlist, and this game came up a few times... Having just spent 10 hours running through the game, I can see now why it's rated so highly. While I'm definitely not a fan of the 'brawler' genre, the way they've fused that with the metroidvania formula so seamlessly makes for a stand-out, excellent title. 

Visuals: I dismissed this game a while ago over what at first seemed like bizarre looking visuals. Looking closer, it's actually a really nice visual style, character models look good and are expressive, backgrounds look vibrant and inviting. A great looking game, and one that runs on low-end hardware no less!

Platforming: Besides following the metroidvania formula of side-scrolling exploration very well, the platforming itself is some of the most engaging I've encountered in any platformer, period. Every new combat/traversal move learned throughout the game is used to the fullest, and even gets downright diabolical, in some of the more secret areas.

Combat: The combat could be a challenge for me at times (brawlers aren't really my thing), but I couldn't deny that it was fun, even if I did get frustrated at times (a couple of times having to consult a walkthrough to teach me a winning strategy). Almost every traversal move has a combat application as well, so the combat gets ever deeper the further into the game you get. The bosses are all very well designed... although each one just boils down to pummeling them into submission, I found them all nonetheless to be unique and engaging each in their own way.

Story: While not an overly deep story, it's delivered quite well, at times in a very humorous way, at other times slightly more serious. There are, if I counted right, four towns you come across during the course of game, helping the world that's been designed here not to feel empty... every town has at least one side quest for you to do as well, though none of the quests are that deep or engaging.

Got it on sale for $4.37 CAD, was definitely well worth the purchase! If your budget permits you to get it at full price, I'd say it's still well worth the purchase, even if the experience is relatively short.

94686546.review:
This is such a strange game.

Formula-wise, it's pretty standard stuff. It's a metroidvania with character action game elements. You find powerups and expand your kit to include new traversal and combat options, and enemies become more complex and encounters more puzzle-oriented as your progress. It's mostly good and fluid, but sometimes special move inputs are unresponsive, and hitboxes are occasionally vague.

However, the writing is full of weird and conflicting energies.

I don't know how else to describe it. This is a game that is earnest and deep and shallow and banal.

The art is gorgeous. Consistently, stylistically, sound as hell. The character designs pop, and everything feels like it fits perfectly together.

The writing is inconsistent. The overall tone is sort-of-comedy, and sometimes the characters are extremely likeable and compelling. There's a lot of Spanish peppered into the dialog, but it feels more like how people write bilingual dialogue rather than how bilingual dialog actually is. Some beats hit super hard, some whiff, and there's a lot of 2010s era nerd culture references scattered throughout (Castle Crashers, Rooster Teeth, Strong Bad, etc)---all with unexpectedly high effort in-game posters.

The setting's mythology feels interesting, and the art makes it feel grounded and mystical and lush.

At no point was I able to figure out whether the game was making a caricature out of Mexico or an earnest homage.

Taken as a whole, I think I have to say that I liked Guacamelee. There are better metroidvanias, but the art here is so good that it's impossible not to recommend it on visuals alone.

If you're on the fence, it's worth a try.

Edit: The platforming gets a little bit Path Of Pain towards the end, to the point where there was a progress-essential room in the last 1% of the game that I couldn't figure out. I'd done all the optional stuff and had the chicken flight final upgrade, but the room was built specifically to block it from working. So, idk. I'll never see what the last bit of gameplay was like. I youtubed the ending.

94141857.review: Recommends using a controller, then doesn't account for input delay in more advanced challenges / reflex puzzles, requiring user to both have lightning reflexes for "picture perfect" actions (dodging through vines) and fully account for trigger delays, providing zero coyote time for input while demanding exact frame actions. I played this game a while back and had actually enjoyed it quite a lot at the time so tried to come back for that fun, tight and RESPONSIVE challenge I remember. Was greatly disappointed, seems my memory was wrong, as evidently worse input control than Skul & Dead Cells.

93784411.review:
Gold Edition is a fantastic single player art piece and genuinely challenging game.
Turbo Edition is a "party game" (2+ players). It's the tex-mex BBQ and Monster-truck Rally version.

Gold edition is substantially better. Unfortunately stce pile-drives Guacamelee's otherwise flawless pacing and story. The Canals are fine, but the side-story with the "Terrible Trio" is actually terrible. It's not especially long or hard, but it interrupts the Sierra Morena sequence and includes one of those BS insta-kill chase rooms, along with trapped arenas. Intenso is just an annoying rage-mode they threw in. It honestly adds nothing to the game, accept a crutch for lower skill players.

Even so, I'd still rate stce at 7/10
It's just that I'd give Gold Edition a solid 9/10

I recommend getting the bundle that includes both. That way you can make up your own mind.

English review:
Guacamolee is a indie metrovania platform game. The graphic is very pleasant and colorful and it takes inspiration from mexican floklore. I found the gameplay very smooth and it isn't a punitive game as many similar games where you have to make 100% accurate jumps or you have to repeat the same point 1000 times until it leads you to frustration.
In the game there are several save point and custumes so you can change your main character aspect whenever you want. During the game you can unlock new special moves and combo to beat enemies.
Music is very nice if you like the mexican traditional Mariachi style even if sometimes it could be just a bit repetitive. There is even the co-op mode to play with your buddy on same computer or with remote play, but I never tried this mode.

If you like eating burritos with guacamolee and mexican wrestling luchadores this is the game for you!

Italian review:
Guacamalee è  un gioco indie di tipo platform metrodvania. La grafica è molto piacevole e colorata e prende ispirazione dal folklore messicano così come la musica. Ho trovato il gioco molto scorrevole e non punitivo a differenza di molti platform attuali dove devi calcolare il salto al millimetro altrimenti ti ritrovi a  ripetere lo stesso punto un migliaio di volte fino alla frustrazione. Nel gioco ci sono diversi save points e costumi aggiuntivi che ti permettono di cambiare l'aspetto del protagonista. Nel corso della storia si sbloccheranno nuove mosse aggiuntive e combo per poter far fuori gli scagnozzi. Le musiche sono piacevoli se vi piace lo stile Mariachi della tradizione messicana anche se alle lunga può risultare un pochino ripetetiva. C'è anche la modalità co-op sullo stesso computer o in remote play che però non ho mai avuto il modo di provare.  
Se vi piacciono i burrito con guacamolee e i luchadores del wrestling messicano questo è il gioco che fa per voi!

91024579.review:
This is an above average 2D platformer with beat-em up-style combat. I definitely recommend it for fans of the genre. However, there are a number of negatives I have with the game, and other games I would recommend over it. I got Guacamelee on sale for ~$4 and found it well worth it at that price, but much more than that and I may have been hard to recommend.

Note: I played this game single player, and thus my review is for a single player experience, but if you are looking for a multiplayer game in this genre, this this game is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED because there isn't as much quality competition.

I would recommend these games on Steam before Guacamelee:
- Monster Boy and the Cursed Kingdom [single player 2D platformer]
- Wonder Boy The Dragon's Trap [single player 2D patformer]
- The Shantae games (Half-Genie Hero, Pirate's Curse, Seven Sirens, Risky's Revenge) [single player 2d platformers]
- Streets Of Rage 4 [multiplayer beat-em up]

Here are some of my negative opinions of the game...

The sound in this game sucks. The music all feels like stock music and doesn't really elevate the game in any way. The sound effects (or lack thereof are even worse than the music). Sound effects are really important in beat-em ups so that your attacks feel impactful especially considering how much you will be mashing the attack button. But the sound effects of the basic attacks sound like whooshing noises rather than the typical beat-em up sounds. There is also no voice acting. There is more dialog than you might expect from a game in this genre, and that makes the lack of voice acting hurt a bit.

The game is fairly short. I was able to beat the game on my first blind play though in ~4 hours. I did NOT 100% the game, so if you want to 100% the game that will add a lot of time, but I don't really have an urge to do that myself. Guacamelee DOES NOT HAVE A GOOD COLLECTIBLE MAP. It shows you collectibles per area, but it does not show you the locations/which you already collected. Compare this to "Monster Boy and the Cursed Kingdom" that has a map that shows every collectible location on it.

The game is too  easy. Not once did I struggle with the game. That goes for both the platforming and the combat. That doesn't mean it isn't fun, but more challenge would have gone a long way. I didn't even realize you could buy upgrades from save spots until nearly the end of the game. I just never needed any buffs because there was no challenge.

The character is a bit sluggish. There are a lot of actions that require a lot of frames for the character to recover. After every special move that is a a fraction of a second before you can attack or dodge again. When you get hit, your character must fall all the way to the ground before you regain control. You can change your trajectory mid jump, but not very much without using a special. The character clings to walls ALL THE TIME. Sometimes I want him to get off the wall but he just won't let go of the walls. You can also only use each type of special once (except for the vertical wall run) before stepping on horizontal ground again. Specials also kill your momentum. I understand why they made some of these decisions, but it would have been nicer if the character felt a little faster/smoother.

The graphics could be better. The animations usually look fairly cheap (but this isn't a AAA game to be fair). A few spots in the game the enemies were similar colors to the backgrounds and I didn't actually notice them at first. Also when there are a lot of enemies on screen, they will overlap, and your attacks have an effect, so it just becomes a jumbled mess sometimes that you can't follow because everything is overlapping.

The hit boxes. This is pretty minor, but I found that a lot of hit boxes don't really match their visual representation. An annoyance, but once you trial-and-error the hitbox it isn't bad.

The comedy. This game has a lot of comedy, and it just didn't do it for me.

90891877.review:
The game's art style is fun, the writing and characters are enjoyable and I really digged the skill progression parts (the goat's animation had me every time). Most boss fights are rewarding even if you need a few tries.

Where there's light, there is also shadow.

Some environment puzzles appeared to be put into place just to annoy people. Having to remember a maze-like structure beforehand because for no reason at all your screen gets limited to just a small section around the character for the first and only time in the game felt unnecessary. And especially the "Tree Tops" area was highly frustrating. After about half an hour of slow progression upwards without any save points or teleport options I got stuck in the last section. With sweat dripping from my gamepad and nowhere else to go the game now forced me to drop all the way down again, seeing my hard earned progress fleeting by.

Also if after a few hours of playing I still confuse two of the buttons it would've been great to just remap them. However the gamepad button configuration is fixed.

If you like easy to learn and hard to master platformers, Guacamelee is probably for you. I liked it for the most part, but can't excuse the frustration it also caused.

After finishing the final boss, the game tells me, "Hard Mode" is now available. No thanks.

I'm inclined to give this a thumb down but then the pros still quite outweight the cons so I will keep it as thumb up, but be aware:

The whole game was good. Can say it's pretty great. Story is pretty straightforward. I know quite a number complain about the [spoiler]combo chicken[/spoiler]. It's kinda hard, but still manageable. A bit pointless though since you're not going to use most of those [spoiler]combo[/spoiler] anyways, but if you treat it as "doing this to get items", then still ok.

The challenges are hard, but that's why they are called challenge right?

However, there are 2 kinda frustrating parts:
1) The first one is the [spoiler]disappearing platform on the mountain[/spoiler]. It's hard, but the worst is, it's not even matching the style of the whole game. You can feel pretty clearly that this part was merely added to make the section really really difficult.

2) The difficulty spike at the final final battle. [spoiler]The second form of Calaca[/spoiler]. To me, the whole game was almost a walk in the park. Maybe I will die randomly when I'm being too relax. Most of the bosses was beaten on the first try (which mean I walk into it without knowing but still managed to just win) or at most second try (after learning the pattern), but when it come to the last one, suddenly it took me like 10~20 tries. 
I'm not complaining that the boss fight is hard or if you should tone it down. I'm complaining about the difficulty surge. Unlike some other game that ask you to "git gud" from the start and that the boss difficulty increase as you go, this one feel like everything was way too easy then suddenly the last one is a massive road block. Maybe balance it a bit will be better so at least we got to train along the way.

Anyways, good game still. I've got the second one and hopefully have time to play it soon.

88710989.review:
A colorful, charming, funny metroidvania with its own distinct style built around Mexican culture. It doesn’t exactly try to push the genre’s boundaries, but it does carve itself a nice, comfy and memorable corner within them.

Despite being rather straightforward and linear, it has a nice progression of upgrades that feels like you gradually get access to every nook and cranny (starting from a single jump and going up to wall-running and even a sort of flying). There’s a decent amount of combat where you throw the enemies all around the place (as is suitable for a luchador hero) and perform some nice aerial combos. The controls might feel a bit unresponsive at first, with a slight delay before most actions, but I got used to it very quickly.

Better yet, I think the game truly captures the genre’s signature feeling of discovery thanks to the collectibles you need for the good ending. Placed in particularly well-hidden areas, each locked behind a unique challenge, they do a great job at communicating “Hey, you’ve found something really special!” without using a single line of dialogue. Furthermore, the good ending itself is indeed quite happier than the standard ending and manages to provide heartfelt closure even to such a simple comedic story, so the reward truly carries weight.

Getting all achievements is fairly easy here and took me around 20 hours, though it does require you to replay the main storyline on Hard. Alternatively, you can start with the Hard mode [url= https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=822241534]right away[/url], but that might prove a bit frustrating.

AMAZING GAME
Pros
1. The scenery is amazing .
2. Short but well written story. The story is funny and sad. 
3. A LOT of references to other games!
4. Easy combat but hard combos if you decide to get the chicken training achievement.
Cons

84261995.review: Uno de los mejores metroidvanias de los últimos años. La jugabilidad es, sin duda, su punto fuerte con un sencillo pero adictivo sistema de combos y combinación de poderes que permiten acceder a nuevas zonas. Estos mismos también son aplicados al plataformeo del juego, el cuál es exigente sin llegar a ser injusto o cansino. La ambientación, el soundtrack y el estilo de arte son otro punto a destacar y dan un aire bastante único que hace de la obra algo más que disfrutable (en especial si se es latino). Finalmente, pese a que su duración es corta y la historia no es nada del otro mundo, hay desafíos y coleccionables que contribuyen a alargar y mejorar la experiencia. Un juego extremadamente recomendable que suele encontrarse con descuentos bastante atractivos y que vale totalmente la pena. Un sólido 9/10.

84228039.review:
This is a console ported 2D platformer/brawler with a simplistic animation artstyle and a rich Mexican luchadore theme.

Often the use of this kind of art style is done because the developers are lazy or lack talent to arrange anything better, but in this case a lot of work went into it and it looks okay.  The game features excellent writing and a fun story, which really helps things along.  On the downsides, well, at heart this is still a console game and the gameplay is just a repetitive platformer/brawler with less than perfect controls, and not really well suited to KB+M.   It's worth noting the developers superseded the "Gold" edition of the game with this Super Turbo edition, but leave that on the store out of sheer greed.  That's unacceptable.

It's a shame to see good artwork and a fun story being wasted on an old, dead game format, but there's a reason these things should stay on consoles where the peasants like that kind of thing.   Also, $21.50 for a 2D platformer?  No way.

81502289.review:
A mí personalmente no me gustado mucho, quizá por la temática o porque me parece muy simple en su género o puede que sea porque no está del todo pulido pero lo más seguro es que el motivo se componga de la suma de las tres cosas más alguna otra y aún con todo esto lo recomiendo porque es asequible, un buen comienzo para iniciarse en los metroidvania (aunque no es puramente de este tipo de juegos), es colorido y con un estilo muy marcado, tiene buena ambientación y es divertido pero es que a mí se me ha quedado muy pequeño.
Soy muy aficionado a este género y otros similares y tal vez el haber jugado ya a muchos hace que el siguiente título que juegue lo tenga más difícil para engatusarme. Guacamelee es muy sencillo y, aunque no es fácil, es poco desafiante, otra cuestión es que quieras sacarte el 100% y ahí es donde el juego aprieta pero de una forma un tanto injusta. Sacar el final bueno recolectando las esferas esas raras y pasarse con oro todos los desafíos del Infierno te aprieta las tuercas y estoy seguro de que la gran mayoría pasará de todo esto porque ahí sí que se hace tedioso. Las pruebas esas del Infierno son difícles y algunas están muy ajustadas en tu contra de modo que superar la marca que te indican cuesta y mucho. Pero lo demás es un paseo incluso en Difícil.

Lo bueno:
-Su estética, aspecto visual y ambientación musical te transportan a este enorme estereotipo mexicano con forma de juego que es Guacameleé. Supongo que a alguien de ese país le puede parecer hasta ofensiva esta colección de clichés o tal vez le haga gracia, no sé, pero no se puede decir que el juego no representa a ese país y habrá que destacar eso.
-Es entretenido, a mí no me ha convencido del todo y no es un juego que me haya divertido en especial pero entiendo que, objetivamente hablando, te gustará lo suficiente como para seguir jugando por su sencillez y rápido avance por el juego, estás cada poco consiguiendo cosas, peleando,... es ameno.
-Las peleas están llenas de posibilidades, hay muchos combos, poderes y habilidades tanto ofensivas como de desplazamiento rápido por los escenarios. Al final siempre acabas usando las mismas cuatro técnicas y se acabó porque recordar todos esos combos, algunos bastante largos y poco intuitivos, es algo casi imposible y que no merece la pena.
-Tiene dos finales, desafíos, plataformeo, secretos, muchas peleas, skins,... no está escaso en contenido pero tampoco es un derroche.
-Hay quests secundarias, pueblitos, gente con la que hablar, tiene cierta vida el mundo aquí representado.

Lo malo:
-Su historia es una tontería pero no sé si realmente contar esto como algo negativo porque por un lado dudo que sea así porque sus creadores no tengan capacidad para inventar algo mejor sino que es algo premeditado y por otra parte a nadie que juegue le va importar lo más mínimo la trama.
-Muy simple en mecánicas y jugabilidad. No inventa nada ni lo mejora y se queda por debajo de muchos otros juegos del género porque parece más un plataformas mezclado con un juego de peleas tipo God of War (salvando y mucho las distancias) y todo ello muy simplificado y es por esto que a mí no me ha gustado mucho, no me ha aportado nada.
-Es un cliché andante.
-El control, siendo decente, es fallón. No siempre responde a lo que ordenas y muchas veces los saltos son bastante falsos más alguna que otra cosa de esas que hacen que no confíes en el juego, sabes que vas a fallar bastantes veces por culpa de no estar pulido este aspecto.
-Algunas pruebas del Infierno son bastante injustas e insufribles. Mención especial a una en la que debes llevar un pollo por un circuito pegándole y lanzándolo por ahí, horrible. No sé cómo fui capaz de sacar todos los oros.
-Personalmente creo que tiene muy baja rejugabilidad, solo si eres muy completista repetirás y probablemente resignado.
-La música está bien pero es muy protagonista en el juego, quiero decir que casi todos los temas son más bien fuertes y también de melodías cortas que se repiten una y otra vez hasta que sales de la zona, a mí me cansó bastante y le bajé el volumen, algo que no suelo hacer en otros juegos.
-Hay habilidades y sobre todo combos que parecen estar ahí más por parecer que hay mucho contenido que por ser útiles.
-La dificultad es muy irregular.

Alguna cosa más hay pero bueno, eso es lo que quise destacar. Recomendado pero con muchos matices, si buscas algo elaborado, un reto justo o alguna innovación ni te acerques; si buscas algo simple sin más intención que entretener, es una buena opción, no tardarás mucho en acabarlo y te hará pasar el rato, puede que hasta te encante pero no dejará de ser un juego más, al menos en mi opinión.

Nota: 6

Metroidvania; casi un beat em up pero en realidad mucho mucho más orientado a plataformeo.
El progreso en la historia, y el 'leveo' y los upgrades dependen de explorar y plataformear, obligandote a encontrar la solución en sus puzzles a base de encadenar saltos y combos. Con desafíos de esta naturaleza en cada escenario de cada mapa.
Aunque en realidad siempre es todo opcional (excepto por la parte en que necesitas atravesarlos para avanzar en la historia jaja)

Relativamente fácil y liviano (incluso en su "modo dificil") Así que perfecta opción para jugar en cooperativo local si buscas algo sencillo y que no te dé dolores de cabeza.

Además está llena de una curiosa y divertida temática mexicana, basándose totalmente en esa maravillosa cultura para ambientar con música, colores, decoraciones con festividades del día de los muertos (de hecho los enemigos son esqueletos). 77470049.review:
Guacamelee is an action-platformer game that combines Mexican cultural elements, vibrant visual aesthetics, and captivating gameplay. Developed by DrinkBox Studios, the game has garnered a dedicated fan base with its fun-filled atmosphere, charismatic characters, and exciting challenges. In this analysis, we will explore the positive aspects of both Guacamelee and its sequel, Guacamelee 2, including their gameplay, story, and visual appeal.

Thrilling Gameplay:
Guacamelee stands out for its fast-paced and engaging gameplay. Controlling the protagonist, Juan Aguacate, you dive into a journey filled with frenetic combat, challenging platforming, and creative puzzles. The fluidity of Juan's movements, including acrobatic jumps, powerful strikes, and special abilities, makes the gameplay exhilarating and rewarding.

The progression in the adventure allows Juan to unlock additional abilities, further expanding his tactical options and providing a sense of growth and evolution throughout the game. The combat is fluid and action-packed, encouraging the mastery of combos and advanced techniques. The variety of enemies and challenging bosses keeps the game captivating and provides a satisfying experience when you overcome each obstacle.

Captivating Story and Characters:
In addition to its thrilling gameplay, Guacamelee features a fun and humorous story. With elements of Mexican folklore and references to popular culture, the plot follows Juan Aguacate on his journey to rescue the president's daughter from the clutches of the villainous Carlos Calaca. The story is skillfully presented, combining comedic moments with emotional ones, resulting in a balanced narrative experience.

The characters in Guacamelee are colorful, memorable, and full of personality. From the enigmatic Tostada to the extravagant and eccentric enemies, each character adds a unique element to the plot and the game's world. The witty dialogue and unexpected events ensure a fun and unpredictable experience throughout Juan's journey.

Visual Appeal and Aesthetics:
The art direction in Guacamelee is simply stunning. The game utilizes a vibrant and rich color palette, blending traditional Mexican elements with a cartoonish art style. The detailed environments are brimming with life and showcase a charming mix of rural and urban elements. The visual effects add layers of depth to the scenery, creating an immersive and captivating atmosphere.

Furthermore, the game's soundtrack is an auditory delight, featuring an infectious blend of traditional Mexican music with modern rhythms. The upbeat melodies and memorable themes perfectly complement the action and ambiance, contributing to the player's immersion in the world of Guacamelee.

77342487.review:
Este juego es muy divertido y no estoy hablando solamente de la jugabilidad, sino en todo aspecto; sus escenarios, la música, los personajes, los diálogos (creo que es mejor poner el juego en inglés, debido al uso de Spanglish) Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition es la versión definitiva de Guacamelee!, creo que esto debería estar claro ya que, esencialmente, es el mismo juego y si aún no has jugado a éste título, recomiendo probar Guacamelee! STCE ya que está mucho más pulida la jugabilidad, en especial las plataformas, además del contenido adicional. 

El día de los muertos ha ganado cierta relevancia en la pasada década, ejemplo de ello son las películas como Coco (2017) o El libro de la vida (2014), y precisamente de esto trata Guacamelee!, acentuándose en el tono cómico, nos cuenta la historia de Juan, un luchador mexicano que va en busca de salvar a la hija del Presidente, de manos del malvado Mariachi muerto Carlos Calaca. Como metroidvania no es mucho lo que tiene para ofrecer, dado que hay títulos que ofrecen mucho más y mejor, pero en cuanto a la acción y diversión que entrega, y el precio, es un título recomendable. 
------------------------------------------------0---------------------------------------------------------------

This game is pretty entertaining, and I'm not just talking about its playability, but every aspect; the background, the soundtrack, the characters, the dialogues (I think choosing English is the best option since it uses Spanglish in most dialogues)  Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition is the definitive edition of Guacamelee! I think that this must be clear, since in essence, STCE and Gold Edition are pretty much the same game, though STCE has a much more polished playability, especially in platforms and it also has additional content.

El Día de los Muertos has gained relevance during the last decade, which is seen in movies such as Coco (2017) and The Book of Life (2014) and that's what Guacamelee it's about: whie focusing in the funny tone, it tells the story of Juan, a mexican luchador who goes in the quest of saving the Presidente's daughter from the hands of the evil dead mariachi Carlos Calaca. As a metroidvania it doesn't have much to offer, for the are other titles which deliver much more and better, but repect to the action and fun it gives, and the price, its a recommended title.

76004679.review:
[h1] If you want to buy this, get the One-Two Punch for consoles. [/h1]

I really wanted to be able to write a positive review of the PC port. I was willing to look past a lot of things, like STCE being late, and enjoy the game. That's the kind of gamer I am. As long as I get all the gameplay elements in the end, I'm happy. Unfortunately, this is not the case here, minor as some folks will probably call it. 

The reason I cannot recommend this port is because it never properly got a DLC pack the console versions did called "Frenemies". Instead, Drinkbox put the cosmetic half on the Steam workshop and called it good. Problem is, those skins had unique modifiers that changed how the game played on consoles that for some reason, never reached PC. This is especially confusing considering the sequel did the same thing but [i] did [/i] include it for PC. Given half the material needed was already there, there's no excuse the first game can't have the full package either. I could see putting the skins on workshop as a freebie for people who just wanted that part and had to wait so long, but that doesn't excuse Drinkbox from being lazy. And this was pretty dang lazy.

I do recommend this game. The atmosphere is great, the soundtrack is full of catchy Mexican beats, the story and characters are funny and well-written and the gameplay is a fun combo of metroidvania and light fighter. I just recommend doing so on console so you get the whole gameplay package. Plus, the One-Two Punch pack has a neat manual like in the old days, all the DLC and Bandcamp links to the OSTs along with the added benefit of portability if you get the Switch version. 

Just don't give your money to the port that pulled an unbelievably lazy move.

74826964.review:
Controller Type: Xbox Controller

Completion Status: Finish main story (probably not going to 100 percent it)

Hours Played: 8.2 hrs


Guacamelee! is an indie game developed by DrinkBox games, and it follows the main protagonist Juan, and takes place in Mexico with Day of the Dead as the recurring motif and theme of the game. This game gets slept on pretty often, as I haven't really heard anyone recommending this game before, and so here I am recommending the game to you.

The story of the game is simple. If you're familiar with Day of the Dead (or you watched Coco), then basically the story will be pretty easy to follow. People that are dead come back to life and try to take over the world of the living, it's pretty simple. The dead people's leader is called Calaca, and he has abducted Juan's childhood friend and probably his current girlfriend. The game is incredibly light in tone, and has the right amount of humour so it won't be forced. I absolutely love the references to different games, in particular Mario. There were several Mario references in the game, such as a poster, and the classic quote, "Sorry your princess is in another castle!" The music in this game is also absolutely phenomenal, it fits within the game and it sounds light and awesome.

Guacamelee is a game focused on combos. The nature of the game is to avoid losing your combo streak and try to sustain it as long as possible. The gameplay is incredibly satisying. Seeing skeletons smash to bits with that loud crunchy sound effect is awesome. It's hard to explain how awesome it is until you play it. The game is also very color coded, so colorblind people will need to beware. There are 5 types of "energy punches" in the game. Some enemies will have a coloured shield around them, and you need to use an energy punch of the same color to break that shield in order to deal damage. This mechanic works nicely in the game, so that each combat encounter won't be a mindless sequence of mashing buttons, but you would actually need to think and strategise each move.

The gimmick of Guacamelee comes here. Around 2-3 hours into the game, you will get the ability to swap between worlds - the world of living and the world of the dead. Well so what's the difference? It's a little hard to explain, but I will try to explain as best as I can. Basically in a level there will be some hidden tiles, if you switched to the other world then those tiles will appear. This system is often used in platforming, but it is often used in combat as well. Some enemies will be in the world of the living, some in the world of the dead. If you're in the world of the living and your enemy is in the dead and vice versa, you will not be able to damage the enemy. Again, this is color coded as well because enemies that cannot be damaged yet will be entirely black. Personally, I like this mechanic a lot too. As I said before, this turns a mindless sequence of mashing buttons into something more fun and interesting.

Unlike other metroidvanias like Hollow Knight, Guacamelee is very small in nature. There will be backtracking, but they will not be tedious at all. Checkpoints are incredibly close to each other, so if you die don't worry about traveling for like a long time to get to your previous spot. As a metroidvania, Guacamelee will also involve collecting skills at one point, then backtrack to a previous location to use that skill to unlock a new area. There are a lot of skills in the game, and since the game's world is not very big and the game is quite short, you will find yourself unlocking skills quite often. As I said, don't worry about the backtracking because you won't need to take a very long time.

In conclusion, Guacamelee is a fantastic game, and I highly recommend you to get it.

73095360.review:
Got this when it was free as a fluke. Fun game, but gets tiresome fast, and definitely not worth the money unless you REALLY need a spare metroidvania in your life.

Pros: 
-Interesting combat system
-Lovely folklore backdrop and definitely unique visuals
-Humor that is straight out of the mid 2000's
-Abilities constantly being added to the mix keeps the combat fresh
-The combat generally feels good and combos when YOU are the one freestyling them feel great.

Cons:
-Some arenas are plainly meant to troll the player, filled with platforming and only projectile enemies that aggro from off-screen
-Finicky jumping Puzzles
-So many side quests and challenges that add very little and are just plain frustrating
-More Jumping puzzles
-The game itself feels kinda finicky with timing and button presses for things like jumps, combos and the fixed moves you have to do perfectly for many of the secrets and exploration.
-Yet more jumping puzzles.
-Enough filler content going after secret endings etc that it feels like the game doesn't really respect your time

 I get it's a platformer and metroidvania, but this definitely feels like a game where the devs had more fun making it than most players will actually have experiencing it. It holds up, but just barely, given how many options have come out since its release.

72829674.review:
TL;DR Review
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

Final Score - (7.5) Good

In-Depth Review (Spoiler Free)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

Visuals - 8/10 - (Very Good)
The game is quite beautiful and unique, hardly leaving anything for desires. Even though it is a small world, the areas are quite different from each other giving you a feeling of freshness. The game becomes even more beautiful and fresh when you unlock the ability to change between dimensions and you can experience everything from a new perspective.
Since the game doesn't support 21:9 the black bars can become quite distracting and pull you out of the game's immersion.

Gameplay - 8/10 - (Very Good)
Guacamelee! has some mechanics which are not new to the genre but are executed quite well by mixing your combat abilities with the platformer sections and puzzle-solving.
When it comes to combat the game is quite responsive and smooth, feeling really good to control and hardly ever getting in your way when attempting a combo or string of attacks.
The platforming is well responsive and challenging and is one of the game's strongest assets, completing the platforming areas fell quite rewarding and fun.
All the enemies follow certain patterns of attack and becoming accustomed to them is a must, bosses have unique and fun patterns to master, that makes you feel quite rewarded for defeating them.

Story - 6/10 - (Fine)
The story is quite simple and the classic damsel in distress trope. The girl who is Juan's love interest gets kidnapped by a group of villains and the hero has to save her by defeating the evil bunch. It is simple, but Cohesive and cute enough to serve as a background to the game.

72788744.review:
[h1] El Tigre May Cry [/h1]

[b] Is Samus Aran a Spanish name? [/b]

[b] Metroidvania! [/b] Mostly on the Metroid side this one, is an entertaining stylish air combo filled brawler  side scrolling platformer. 

The strongest part of this game is definitely the combat. If you're good enough, you'll be juggling enemies half a minute at a time like Dante beating a pinata hanging from the Qliphoth tree. The heavy attacks that also double as path openers and traversing methods are mostly well utilized, inside and outside of combat. One of the heavy attacks feels janky but the level design accommodates it well enough that it kinda works? The enemy designs encourage you to use all of the given heavy attacks, so the encounters can be overwhelming if you're not paying attention. The boss fights are pretty great too, not too restrictive in your approach to combat, not too punishing at least on Normal difficulty.

The platforming scenarios and level designs vary in quality. Some parts are cool and feels rewarding to participate in, others especially the late game extra platforming challenges can be awfully frustrating. Awfully.

Striking visuals; the Spanish Día de Muertos festive aesthetic is definitely uncommon in video games. This game is blindingly expressive with its bright colors, cartoon art style, and the levity's there. At least the Easter eggs and video game references in this game isn't as obnoxious as Borderlands'.

This game is a love letter to Metroid front and back, and it is a solid game overall.
Get it.

I think what I like most about this game is that it's easy to either play in short bursts or lose hours in the game. It's also pretty funny at times and the skills are pretty unique for a metroidvania, at least in my experience. 

What I didn't like is that the controls felt wonky at times, often doing the wrong move or going the wrong direction, etc. It could just be my fat fingers, of course, but I don't have the problem to such a degree in other platformers. Still, it's tolerable after making some adjustments and focusing on precision. 

It does feel a bit dated compared to some newer titles, lacking some QoL and polish that it could have benefited from.

71760172.review:
Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition es un metroidvania al más estilo mexicano, con una banda sonora preciosa y con una ambientación que te va a ser creer que realmente estas en Mexico. El juego comienza con un campesino llamado Juan que vive en un pueblucho habitado por otros campesinos muy cordiales, nuetra misión inicial sera ir a la iglesia para ayudar a Fray Ayayay (sacerdote del pueblo) a ayudar con los preparativos para un festival. Cuando estas ayudando al sacerdote aparece la hija del alcalde la cual invita a nuestro personaje a una fiesta que ocurría en la noche. Luego de todo eso debemos ir a ver que ocurrió en la mansión del presidente puesto que estaba en llamas. Al llegar vemos que de la nada nos aparece un esqueleto llamado Carlos Calaca y 2 ayudantes suyos quienes fueron los que iniciaron el incendio hacia la mansión. Carlos nos reta a un combate en el cual morimos de un golpe ya que somos una persona normal. 
Terminamos apareciendo en el mundo de los muertos donde luego de caminar unos metros nos encontramos una mascara de un luchador y vemos tambien que se nos aparece una luchadora llamada Tostada que es la guardiana de la mascara que dice que si nos ponemos podemos regresar al mundo de los vivos y tambien que nos ayudara a derrotar a Carlos Calaca.
Luego de ponernos la mascara volveremos al mundo de los vivos y nos contaran que el villano principal secuestro a la hija del presidente. 
Nuestro objetivo sera salvar a la hija del presidente de las garras de Carlos Calaca ya que tiene pensado utilizarla para un ritual que hará que el mundo de los vivos y el de los muertos se fusionen y así poder dominarlos con sus poderes.
El juego es muy entretenido, con una historia decente, una banda sonora increible, enemigos no del todo dificil al principio pero que mientras vas avanzando en la historia se ponen más complicados llegando algunos a ser tediosos. Mi valoración es: 8,5/10

71125488.review:
I remember as a kid watching Mucha Lucha and thinking, what's the matter with Mexicans? they insist on wrestling with masks on -granted it was a lot of fun to watch, but it always made me wonder as a kid-
then I find this game and I was not surprised when I saw the same tradition being followed here, actually, on the contrary, it made quite happy :)

In Guacamelee Super Turbo Championship Edition, you play as Juan,  Tostada, or maybe a chicken? whoever you might be, in whatever dimension you are, you will always be the brave Luchador of Santa Luchita and its kindhearted people, the Luchador that outsets on an adventure to save his beloved lass and soon enough realizes that he is saving the entire world also.

The world of this small Mexican universe is premeditated to be the best it could be, you never feel lost, out of place, or confused on what's that you are doing or supposed to do and each world is unique -to a certain degree- in its theme and music.

The more you advance in this game the more techniques and abilities you unlock, more combos,  juggles, and throws and new movements that allows you to access locations that weren't accessible before, it makes the game more complex and more fun to play. if this is a downside to you, then this game's only downside is that the closer you get to finishing it the better it gets.

This Metroidvania is Mexicans vibes heavy, humorous, challenging, entertaining to a level I didn't expect, and fun, more fun, and even more fun. I loved this game.
recommended.

70811836.review:
I have to be honest; I hate Gaucamelee Super Turbo Charged Edition. I have heard that the Gold Edition may be a bit better but I believe I would have many of the same problems. I wanted to hate the combat but the move set started to grow on me a bit by the end of the game; however, throwing enemies around and racking up big combos is the only thing keeping the game from being an absolute bust for me. The game claims to be a Metroidvania but I really do not get the feeling of a Metroidvania. I don’t feel that it was ever worth exploring other than when I found pieces of a Luchador mask because the game gated me so hard from exploration early on that when I was told I had 15 statues of power-ups by the old man, I always thought I was going to hit an impassable obstacle. A typical atmosphere of a Metroidvania is lonesome and even fearful. So, when a developer differs from that typical story formula, there needs to be a good reason. There was a good reason to differ and make the story more colourful and light but my god the humour is terrible with some really weird jokes and way too many minor characters. The side quests make this game feel like Zelda where the player is literally rewarded heart pieces. At least the side quests do not tell me exactly where to go like the main game did. I finished this game in one sitting because it just tells me where to go.  Some Metroidvanias have waypoints on a map that are not painfully obvious how to navigate to but the segmenting of the map DOES make it painfully obvious where to go. The world design has no depth! The player gets a blue punch power up; walk out of the room and follow the immediate path with the blue block in the way. Only play this game if you want a more complicated Castle Crashers because it is worthless as a single player experience.
The bosses were pretty bad. There was one cool boss but it ended up not very hard after I got the hang of it. I do not even want to talk about the bosses much because they were just short, straight forward, and the final boss literally made me shed tears of disappointment. I played the entire game to see what was at the end and I wish I had ANY reason to want to look for the pieces of the Luchador mask for the good ending (I presume that is what it is for)… and I do. When I am feeling lifeless, I will try Gold Edition and I might try to get the Luchador mask pieces. For Gaucamelee Super Turbo Charged Edition, the final boss was so terrible with an unfair first phase and only a slightly better second phase that is just as garbage as most of the other bosses in the game.

At the very least, don't play this version of the game.

The game is designed to annoy you. Shields on enemies, shadow/light swap, all of that only exists to make battles annoying. Sometimes VERY annoying. 
Mechanics-wise it's extremely wonky as well. Controls are not intuitive and can't be changed if you use a controller, which is even recommended by the game, so a lot of control fighting is going on. Dodging is a concept, but not practical. The game expects you to be way too precise with all the not very precise movement.

And all of that just gets to the maximum and makes you hate everything in the new and completely enforced content. That was bad. Really really bad. Otherwise it's actually okay. Must've been a typical case of "we did everything with our mechanics that's reasonable, but now we need to make more content for a new version". Please. Next time make it optional. Thanks, That mindset would've saved the game from bad things like the Intenso mode and changed battles for it as well.

70280367.review:
En términos generales Guacamelee! es un Metroidvania muy bien ejecutado. Pero no es sólo eso. Utiliza el esquema del género y lo aplica bien, pero añade elementos de su propia cosecha, como el sistema de combate, muy original, variado y realmente divertido. Tiene contenido para que la historia principal, de unas seis horas, se alargue hasta las quince o veinte si queremos completar el 100%. La dificultad máxima es desafiante tanto en combate como en plataformeo, pero nunca exige más de lo necesario, manteniendo un magnífico equilibrio entre desafío y diversión. Y, para rematar, tiene personalidad. Su estilo de dibujo, ambientación, banda sonora, personajes, enemigos y jefes son realmente característicos, aportando mucho al resultado final del título. 70151876.review:
For the most part Guacamelee! STCE is a fun Metroidvania style platformer.  The game is very colorful and has a fun soundtrack.  My SO is a Day of the Dead enthusiast and as such I'm around it a bit, so I found the Day of the Dead theme of Guacamelee! to be interesting and enjoyable.  The game also made a ton of references to old retro platform games like Super Mario Brothers, Mega Man and Metroid, plus a number of pop culture references to wrestling, and oddly a large number of Star Wars references, which while amusing, seemed out of place in this style of game.

The Luchador's abilities, that are earned in the same vain as Samus from Metroid, were all fun to use and a blast to chain together into combos during combat or use to get additional air/distance when jumping between platforms.  I'm not good at completing Metroidvania style games, but this one was enjoyable enough that I was able to finish the game within an okay time frame.

The only thing that kept Guacamelee! from being a truly standout game to me was that there were a couple areas that required pinpoint precise jumping that included powers that required such precise timing that I couldn't get past, so it was more preferable to ignore them instead of get frustrated trying to get through them.  I am okay with jumping challenge mechanics, but when the required precision is measured in pixels then it turns from challenging into frustrating tedium then I'm done at that point.  Also, all the Star Wars references in the dialogue just didn't fit an a game with a Hispanic heritage theme.

70090065.review:
[h1][u]The Short and Sweet[/u][/h1]
[u]Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition[/u] is a hybrid beat-em-up / Metroidvania game based on Mexican culture, with a large emphasis on combo-based combat, intelligent approach, and platforming. The story revolves around a farmer named Juan, who is killed by the main antagonist while attempting to save his friend, only to come back possessing the power of a magical mask, which turns him into a powerful Luchador intent on punching, suplexing and bodyslamming his way to victory.

As the player progresses through the game, they unlock more types of powerful attacks, such as large uppercuts and bodyslams, or utility abilities like clinging to or running up walls. Many of the combat abilities end up playing critical roles in platforming segments for their mobility, increasing the depth of the system. Additionally, some enemies can only be defeated by certain attacks, preventing the player from simply using brute force to make their way through any and all situations.

[b][u]Pros[/u][/b]
[list]
[*] The combat requires adaptability and precision from the player, making it a welcome challenge.

[*] Co-op with up to four players is supported, and is Steam Remote Play compatible.

[*] The art style and music is a pleasure to experience, both centered around Mexican culture.

[*] The combination of platforming and solid combat mesh well together, often overlapping for even more entertainment.

[*] The story and dialogue are entertaining throughout, and are definitely not a detriment to the experience.
[/list]

[b][u]Cons[/u][/b]
[list]
[*] Metroidvania’s style of backtracking can be a major turn-off for many players. Getting a lot of the upgrades requires backtracking, as does the “True Ending”. Both can rapidly become tedious if you choose to pursue them, but they are not necessary to complete the game, and can be ignored if desired. However, you are missing a large amount of content if you choose to do this.

[*] Playing with more than one player can quickly become absolute chaos during platforming, as the game has a few key mechanics that all players can control, but need to be precisely handled for successful platforming. Intense coordination can be required to surpass even the simplest of obstacles if playing with friends.
[/list]

[h1]Short Conclusion: Recommended[/h1]

[h1][u]In-Depth Analysis[/u][/h1]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Guacamelee is a beat-em-up first and foremost. It primarily focuses on the combo system, encouraging the player to chain together as many hits as possible for the maximum amount of damage. This is fueled by the combo meter, a bar that shows the player how many times they can use their upgraded combat abilities before having to recharge. This, just like the health bar, is made larger by gathering upgrade pieces scattered across the game. 

Many enemies are coated in a colored shield that requires the player to use the matching ability on them in order to do damage. Multiple enemies can appear in a single area, each with a different shield color, and all shields eventually regenerate if not damaged for a few seconds, meaning Guacamelee expects the player to be a fast strategist and a good brawler. Combos are satisfying to pull off and deal large amounts of damage, helping to secure a kill before moving on to other enemies.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2114577601

The platforming is what you would expect from a platforming game, but gains extra depth with the implementation of the same abilities one would normally use for combos. A jump can be made higher with an uppercut, or longer with a dash. Many times a specific color-coded block requires a specific move to destroy, just like shields. This makes the platforming more enjoyable than the vanilla jump-n-climb every veteran gamer has become accustomed to by now.

Unfortunately, in order to unlock the “True Ending” of the game, the player must backtrack to reach multiple additional areas that are filled to the absolute brim with pure challenge platforming and combat. Two of them in particular are very, very time consuming and can be a major pain for players that don’t care much about challenge for the sake of challenge. I’ve been told [u]Guacamelee! Gold[/u] does not have these problems, as it was released before this edition, but as I have not played Gold or the original, I cannot speak on these problems.

 [h1]Story[/h1]
The story is entertaining in execution, but simple in overall plot. You are the hero going to rescue the girl. The player interacts with a wide variety of characters in this quest, some more interesting than others, and nearly all very entertaining to listen to. 
The game is absolutely riddled with comedy and references to other forms of media, making it almost worth playing for the story alone. But this story is merely the glue that holds all the combat and platforming together to form the Guacamelee experience.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
Guacamelee takes inspiration from Day of the Dead culture and Aztec designs to form a pleasing hybrid of rugged, chiseled shapes and decorated displays that I wholly enjoy looking at the entire time I am playing.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2114582753

The design of the game is very angular and sharp in nature, avoiding a lot of curves on important pieces. This strong and stylized form of art helps it to stand out among other games. The visuals are definitely a plus for Guacamelee.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Punches have impact and abilities give satisfying thumps, but the real winner of audio for Guacamelee is the music. Just like the art, it takes a heavy influence from traditional Mexican music, with a focus on guitars, trumpets, and vocals that are a joy to listen to. There’s just something about that combination of instruments and vocals that I can’t seem to get enough of. If you like mariachi music, like me, you’ll like Guacamelee’s music.

[h1]Technical[/h1]
[u]Specs:[/u] GeForce 840m 2GB, 8GB Memory, i7 CPU, Windows 8.1

I had zero problems running Guacamelee at 60fps, 1080p. However unlike most games, I experienced very noticeable and very annoying amounts of screen tearing with V-Sync turned off. Thankfully, the game is easy enough to run that turning on V-Sync had no impact on my ability to play at 60fps.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
While the Metroidvania nature may turn away some prospective gamers that dislike the focus on backtracking, most of the backtracking can be safely ignored if desired, allowing the player to focus solely on the solid combat / platforming gameplay, engaging story and culture-rich atmosphere. While it is perfectly fine solo, beware some gameplay complications if playing with a friend. 

Overall, at $14.99, I would say it is worth the price if you are a fan of the Metroidvania style, but it also goes on sale quite often at 50% or more. It is a competent game worthy of consideration by any player that finds these features exciting.

[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/23741321]Follow our curator page[b] Alexander's Club Curations[/b], if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]

69961496.review:
[h1]Está Bien[/h1]

[b][i]Guacamelee! es un beat´em up estilo metroidvania divertido sobre cultura mexicana que no se me hizo ni muy largo, ni muy cansado, a pesar de tener partes muy tediosas.[/i][/b]

[u]Los personajes[/u] están bien construidos, todos tienen sus razones personales para hacer lo que hacen y personalidades definidas.

La mayoría de [u]los enemigos[/u] son genéricos, pero con múltiples variantes, que irán apareciendo a medida que la dificultad del juego crece. 

[u]La trama[/u] es una línea recta de principio a fin sin giros de vuelta rebuscados. Se sabe hacia dónde va la historia y como va a terminar es obvio, pero aun así da ganas de jugarlo.

[u]La Jugabilidad[/u] es clásica de un beat´em up con la excepción de que a medida que se progresa en la partida se le van otorgando al luchador “habilidades” (como escalar, doble salto, volar, etc.) que también puede utilizarlas como movimientos de peleas.

[u]Los gráficos[/u] son cómodos y algo minimalistas ya que no muestran gran cantidad de detalles. Personalmente creo que se ajustan bien al juego y funcionan correctamente resultando agradables.

[u]Este juego[/u] cuenta con un modo New game + y un final alternativo. Además, aparte de las misiones principales, existen múltiples misiones secundarias para quienes quieran explorar más el mundo.

[u]Los atractivos[/u] principales de este juego son sin lugar a duda las peleas y la mescla con la cultura mexicana.

[i]Es un juego que no lo recomendaría comprar a más de 100$ (argentinos), sobre todo por lo corta que es la historia, siendo que a mí me duro menos de 7 horas y no me dejo ganas de seguir jugándolo y completando todas las misiones secundarias.[/i]
