69781286.review:
Guacamelee is interesting to say the least, going in to this game you might want to be a fan of metroidvanias, a unique art style (enhanced in guac 2) or be a fan of Mexican interpreted games (I don't believe there were many if any Mexican developers or artists working on this game-  correct me if I'm wrong). Anyway onto the pros and cons of buying this game, cause although this is probably one of my favourite games it still had me very conflicted at some points.

PROS
-Cool art style with unique looking characters and creatures, one of my favourites being Alebrije
-Love the soundtrack and unique boss sounds
-Mostly a good level of challenge that isn't frustrating
-Can play as casual and get through the game in about 8+ hours or for achievements, which for me was 32 hours
-People often say the humour is outdated, such as the references through signs but considering the game is older, is still refreshing to see
-Anyone can play, I think some younger kids would also quite like to play with some help from parents or siblings as the game is suited to both younger and older audience
-Can play local co-op
-I like being able to turn into a chicken

CONS
-Flashing lights when you finish a upgrade (this gets worse in guac 2) can become a bit much after playing the game a while
-Furthering my last point- I wouldn't play for long periods at a time as the game is bright
-Definitely wouldn't recommend playing with a key board, if you're going to buy this game, have a controller you can plug in
-I also wouldn't play too long because it can become irritating to play some of the rooms (where enemies spawn and you have to kill them all before you can leave), especially if it involves the red lava which is basically a restart for that room, also those stupid exploding fly's are a bit excessive and pissed me off but its a challenge I guess

Overall I would recommend this game, it's really fun, I love the story and endings. If anyone is trying to chose between Guacamelee and Guacamelee 2, I promise you Guacamelee 1 is better. Not to diss on 2 but it gets impossibly hard to the level of the optional disappearing platform room in Guac 1. Guacamelee has a good balance of difficulty and you definitely won't regret playing it (as long as you have a controller, cause keyboard is just a death wish)

69750709.review:
Guacamelee! es, en resumen, un muy buen juego plataformero/beat'em up. Aunque se suele englobar también en juegos del tipo metroidvania, en mi opinión destaca más como acción, plataformeo y hostias, ya que, por ejemplo, tampoco le recuerdo nada de backtracking (tener que volver a sitios del mapa). Principalmente avanzas sin complicaciones para orientarse ni puzles, repartiendo "caramelos" y, según vas pasando partes, vas aprendiendo nuevos tipos de golpes.

Aún así, no es un juego sencillo, la dificultad está bien ajustada, y tiene una jugabilidad basada en diferentes golpes/combos muy entretenida y dinámica. El control está pulido y es gratificante, como debe ser en un juego de este estilo.

Gráficamente y musicalmente está bastante bien, todo en consonancia con su inspiración humorístico-mejicana con un aire muy fiestero y de jolgorio, muy colorido todo. La historia es sencilla, y una mera excusa para el juego, no es el punto más importante en este juego. El juego tiene su punto de humor y se hace simpático.

En definitiva, un juego muy divertido y recomendable.

This game is amazing. The aesthetic is novel and interesting. It's a fun take on a Metroidvania that blends a compelling storyline with a BBEG you hate, with a bunch of great comedy. It's also a really interesting celebration on Mexican culture and history. Turns out Lucha Libre is officially recognized by Mexico as part of their cultural heritage, alongside themes of Dia de Los Muertos and pre-colonial civilizations.

Also it's just fun as hell. The inclusion of fighting game grappler mechanics is a cool way to add depth to MV hackandslash, and the polymorph and live-dead world mechanics further the complexity in really challenging ways. 10/10 imo!

Guacamelee! is absolutely sublime. Not just because of the horrible pun of its title. Metroidvania with a luchadore is something the gaming industry hasn't seen before (not counting the Strong Bad adventure titles) and it truly is something the gaming world had needed.

I grew up playing NES, Sega Genesis, and DOS platformers and I adore this game. It has all the same charming qualities that my favorite retro games had; it reminds me most of Wizards and Warriors/Ironsword. It's challenging enough to keep you frustrated but it's beatable enough to keep you coming back.

I enjoy the fact that you can explore the maps freely as you advance through the game; the maps don't get locked out once you pass through them. Even after you beat the game, you can continue collecting achievements at your own leisure.

The art and music are unique and beautiful. The characters are funny and endearing. The ONLY negative I could point out about this game is that the Spanish does not seem to have been proofread. Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone.

66069525.review: So as an adult man who's never played Metroid or Castlevania, I'm suddenly finding myself getting hooked on Metroidvanias. And to be honest, I wasn't really too sure about Guacamelee when it first popped up on my radar: I thought it was over-hyped and I wasn't really impressed by the combat I saw in the trailers. But then I bought it on sale, and when I realized I could suplex and piledrive my enemies into dust... man I was sold. This was a lot funner than I expected - it basically took what I love about beat-em-ups (punch!, kick!, dodge!, dash!, launch!, grab!, SLAM!!!) and mixed it up with everything I've been enjoying about vanias (big maps, hardcore platforming, secret areas, new skills). Everything else is also pretty great - the art-style is stellar, the humor is silly but endearing, there's a lot of neat little easter eggs to find, and the music was really fun. Hell, there's one track in particular that I can really only describe as Mariachi-Dub. It is glorious. Def recommended, and after I clear some of my backlog I'm definitely getting the sequel.

Man, this Shantae game is good. Wait. This isn't sexy ladies and whipping stuff with your hair! What is this?! Well, it's luchavania! Luchadores? Tequila? Kicking ass? Yes, this is it! But how good is it exactly? Let's explore the ups and downs of the game (+, +/-, -, ?):

+Guacamelee's art style is great. Great use of colours, nice designs.
+The soundtrack and sound effects are great.
+The gameplay is tight. Kicking ass feels so good! Skeletons flying and dying everywhere! Yes!
+All power ups and mechanics work well.
+I love all the characters! Beautiful stuff, great monologues!
+This game can definitely make you laugh out loud.
+/-The story is almost interesting. I kept zoning out from time to time. When it comes to the story, the writing could've been better. It's a telenovela, right?
+/-The dungeon design is okay. Going back and forth can suck a lot. But, you know, fast travelling is well done and it makes this less of a problem.
+/-The game is quite short. If you're a speedrunner, you might like this a lot.
-Why's there so much emptiness? At times, I felt like something was missing from the game or maybe the levels could have been designed better.
-The map sucks. Yes, you can see almost everything you need to but... Zooming out? Nah, why'd you need that? The again, zoom iiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiin! Yeah that's useful! *Hotel Mario voice: "No"*
-The boss fights are way too easy. I had more trouble with regular enemies and platforming than any of the bosses.
-I just finished my first playthrough and I have to say, I don't feel the game. This is one of those games that is fun to play, but you'll forget it soon.
? Is this the best version of the game? I've heard that Gold Edition is better. I feel I can review this version better after playing that one.

Guacamelee STC Edition is fun, but it's missing stuff, especially something that would make it really stand out. Great artwork and theme alone just isn't enough for me. For you, this might be a treat, but to me, this game feels similar to Shantae: Half-Genie Hero; It's a good, but flawed game and it is easy to forget. I'll play more of this game and update my review sometime in the future. Currently, I'd give this game a 7,5/10.

63777427.review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#189 out of 555)... it's time for Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition.

I'm not sure exactly why this "Super Turbo Championship Edition" needs to exist as a separate listing on Steam, especially when the original version of the game had already been upgraded to "Gold Edition." In other cases I'd assume it was done to wipe away all of the negative Steam reviews and start over with a fresh slate (as usually tends to be the case) but my understanding is that most everyone loves Guacamelee. And with good reason--it's one of the best and most refreshing metroidvanias in years.

Which I guess makes my opinion on the game pretty obvious: I love Guacamelee. It's got a snazzy art style, catchy music, fun characters, a world that's fun to explore, and really solid combat mechanics that are only very rarely frustratingly difficulty (usually when they combine combat with platforming). The only real complaint I have is that the game supports two-player co-op, and as part of that has a secondary protagonist: a female luchador. So far so good--the problem? Even though you can play the game as the other character, the story is still written with Juan as the hero: it would have been much more fun if the game reacted to the player character, using the appropriate nouns and pronouns and so on. Oh well: plenty of other games have missed better opportunities, so I suppose I shouldn't be too harsh here.

So, yeah: it's a brilliant, imaginative metroidvania with a unique setting and confident humor. If you're fond of the genre, it's most definitely worth your time.

Note: also played on Sony Playstation 4, Sony Playstation Vita and Nintendo Switch.

61769349.review:
Carlos Calaca has kidnapped El Presidente's Daughter, and he plans to sacrifice her in order to merge the World of the Living with the World of the Dead.

Juan Aguacate, an agave farmer who stumbles upon a Legendary Luchador mask, must find the strength and courage to become the Hero he's always dreamed of being and put a stop to this.

Guacamelee! is a Metroidvania-style action-platformer set in a magical world inspired by traditional Mexican culture and folklore. The game features melee combat, parallel dimensions and same-screen co-op. The original Guacamelee! received wide critical acclaim and was a finalist for both IndieCade and the Independent Games Festival's Excellence in Visual Art award.
Key Features
Non-Stop Fighting Action. An extensive move list, advanced combo engine, and anti-gravity grabs
Multi-dimensional Platforming. Instantly swap between the Worlds of Living and Dead to traverse impossible terrain
Combat moves double as movement, uniting platforming and fighting in a way never seen before
Diverse, detailed world containing lively towns, dark forests, flowery canals and fiery volcanoes
Drop in/out 4-Player local co-operative play, featuring independent dimension swapping
Multiple boss characters (each with unique back stories), wide range of foes, and elite-class enemies
Spectacular player abilities: The Rooster Uppercut, Frog Slam, and “Intenso” turbo-combat mode
Create new custom costumes and share these with others via Steam Workshop
Steam leaderboards, achievements and trading cards, support for multiple save slots, persistent cross-save-game costume unlocks
Chickens. Lots and lots of chickens.

*** Please note that the ‘Super Turbo Championship Edition’ of Guacamelee! is an updated version of the previously-released Guacamelee! Gold Edition. ***

61623436.review: [b]Guacamelee[/b] features a rather interesting mix of metroidvania and beat 'em up genres. Absolutely stellar artwork and music, fun gameplay mechanics. On the downside it can get pretty repetitive at times, especially since the difficulty is so casual (very generous dodge roll, many ways to regenerate health, very easy to string combos) and the playtime is padded by very similar challenges (e.g. beat 20 enemies in this room for the doors to open). Don't expect any meaningful exploration, the game is almost entirely linear and you have a quest marker telling you where to go and what to do. Still, I enjoyed my time with the game. If you're running out of metroidvanias and/or 2D action platformers to play, then this is definitely worth picking up.

60958306.review:
[h1] Canta y no llores, porque cantando se alegran cielito lindo los corazones [/h1]

Uno de los mejores metroidvanias con su toque mexicano que he jugado en mi vida.

[h1]Historia:[/h1]
Guacamelee nos presenta la historia de Juan, un tipico pueblerino el cual lleva una vida tranquila trabajando cuando por azares del destino es llamado para luchar contra el ejercito de esqueletos que se han levantado para unir el mundo de los vivos y los muertos dependiendo de ti de que esto suceda.


[h1] Jugabilidad: [/h1]
El combate es uno de los aspectos más importantes de Guacamelee, ya que nos tendremos que abrir paso por varios tipos de enemigos los cuales podemos machacar con nuestros combos a disposición lo que lo hace más interesante.

Una de las mecánicas interesantes es el cambio de mundo, con lo cual Juan puede alternar entre el mundo de los vivos y los muertos, ya que cada sección o pueblo cambia según el mundo en el que estamos se convierte en una gran tarea explorar todos estos rincones.

Por otro lado muchas partes del mapa cuentan con escondrijos o pasadizos ocultos a los cuales podemos acceder con varios superpoderes lo cual lo hace bastante rejugable por si queremos hacernos con todos los objetos y además del [spoiler] final oculto. [/spoiler]

Además del combate, las plataformas, puzzles y exploración que nos encontramos, llegando a ciertos pueblos podemos decidir si queremos ayudar o no a algunos de sus habitantes pero recuerda que estos podrían tener cierta recompensa buena. 

[h1] Gráficos: [/h1]
Es un plataformero en dos dimensiones que cuenta con fondos interactivos que van cambiando dependiendo de la zona de donde nos encontremos y conforme vamos avanzando se nos muestran más y más detalles.

[h1] Banda sonora: [/h1]
Al estar ambientado en México Guacamelee ofrece una banda sonora bastante divertida.

60682198.review:
Mr. Act and I sat down to play this together and after about 30 minutes he turned to me and said, “This is a terrible game.” He was right. He has continued, over the past few days, to intermittently remind me that he hated this game, which frankly is as passionate as I’ve ever seen him about a piece of media.

Ugh, I don’t even know where to start. Probably the worst thing was the level design. The levels were confusing, obtuse, and recursive. Neither of us had any idea where we were or where we had to go in the dungeon at any point, and using the minimap didn’t even help. The puzzles were unintuitive and uninteresting. The way the screen suddenly flashed as you moved from room to room instead of a smooth transition was jarring and disorienting. The button-mashy combat was repetitive and unfun, and button combos were infuriatingly unreliable. The whole thing was a chore to experience.

The game was also stupidly misogynistic. The three women are a) the damsel in distress, about whom everyone says it’s sad she’s in distress because she’s hot; b) the non-story woman second-player character whose tits bounce around; and c) the evil woman who speaks in double entendres and starts freaking out because she’s omgsojealous of the bad guy capturing a hot woman, because women, so emotional. All the male characters, including townies, do nothing but talk about screwing women. Like, the mentor guy who gives you powers introduces himself by talking about fucking your mom and then like, threatens to have sex with her when he thinks you’re slacking off? It’s so goddamn weird. I am also HIGHLY suspicious of three guys named Chris Harvey, Ryan MacLean and Graham Smith writing Mexican people as lecherous assholes. (It also makes the obsession with women’s bodies feel like a fetish thing.) I’m suspicious of them writing a game based on Mexican culture in general, but honestly I couldn’t even get far enough into it to complain about that.

And this is beside the point but also indicative of the amount of thought it feels like was put into this game in general: the title has nothing to do with fucking anything. This is one of those once-in-a-lifetime-sentences: This game is completely unrelated to guacamole. They just chose a random ~Mexican~ thing and made a stupid portmanteau out of it. They didn’t bother to find an actual word in Spanish and make a clever pun, they just went HUR HUR YOU CAN GET GUACAMOLE AT MEXICAN RESTAURANTS SO LET’S CALL OUR GAME THAT.

I’d be very curious to know if there are any games out there about Mexican/South American culture by a Latinx team/head writer/etc., because this seems like a cultural moment in which that kind of art is super necessary, but this is very very much not that game. (Update: Aritana and the Harpy’s Feather has been on my list for a while, can’t believe I forgot about it. Also, some googling has led me to Mulaka and not much else.)

58921548.review:
This game has a very strong foundation. It's so strong that it almost became one of my favourite Metroid-vania games of all time. Unfortunately, the game doesn't build upon this foundation to any significant degree. In fact, it actually detracts from it and therefore ends up just being a great game rather than a fucking awesome game.

The foundation of this game is very simple. You have your 3 hit attack combo. When you hit enemies with your attacks enough time, you can "grapple" them. This grapple has 3 functions:
	• AOE attack: After you grapple an enemy, you can throw an enemy in any direction. When thrown, the enemy will knock down any other enemies in the way.
	• Attack reset: Right after you throw an enemy, you can repeat your 3 hit attack combo. Surprise surprise, most enemies can be grappled after 3 hits.
	• Invulnerability: While you're grappling an enemy, you're invulnerable to any damage. This allows you to dodge attacks and carefully aim enemies to fly in the direction you want them to.

Because of how useful the grapple is, the developers have been able to create a combo focused system witch just 2 attacks (3 hit combo and grapple). Simple and effective.

As you progress in the game, the combat slowly gets built upon using special moves. These special moves are basically heavy attacks that attack in a certain direction (up, down, left/right, stationary). These special moves ALSO reset your attacks. This is very useful for big enemies that can't be grappled. So far so good. You can use grapples to take on multiple small enemies and special moves to take on large enemies.

I thought the combat would progress to link all of these attacks together so that you would be doing really long combos while fighting many enemies all at once. That would've been really cool….. But unfortunately the enemy design stops this from happening. The small enemies' health pool is too small, so they die in like 2 combos (e.g. 3x attack --> special move ---> 3x attack = dead enemy). You can't do a long ass combo on an enemy that dies so quickly. The big enemies' don't get stunned, and they attack in the time it takes you to do 2 combos. Therefore, unless you want to take damage, you're forced to dodge and restart your combo. 

While the above is limiting, the late-game enemies are the worst. This is where the foundation of the game starts deteriorating. Late-game enemies, including bosses, automatically dodge after taking a certain # of hits in the MIDDLE of your combo. This was a really bad design decision. Note that it's the # of hits, not the damage. Therefore, combat against these enemies is all about spamming your special moves since they do the most damage per hit.  You almost never want to use your regular attacks OR grapple and so combat is actually more boring in the late game compared to the early to mid-game. Keep in mind that special moves take energy, so you'll be spamming your special moves, waiting until your energy recharges, and repeat the process.

To be fair, combat definitely becomes more challenging as the game progresses. This is because of the way fights are designed. You're not really fighting enemies 1 on 1 as you move throughout the world like in most Metroid-vania games. Instead, most fights happen in square arenas (e.g. you can be exploring and then walls appear to the left and right of you. Enemies start spawning in and you can't leave until you beat all the enemies). These arenas can have various hazards and multiple enemies can spawn in an arena, forcing you to take on multiple enemies while being wary of your surroundings. Furthermore, late game enemies have "shields", which require a very specific special move in order to break the shield. Late game enemies also have some attacks that can't be dodged, forcing you to double-jump/wall jump over them. So while YOUR attacks get more limited (i.e. you're just spamming super moves rather and not normal attacking and grappling), the enemies' attacks and defenses get more varied and interesting. I died multiple times on certain groups of enemies and got a great feeling of achievement when I beat them.

There's only 5 bosses in the game, but they're all very distinct from each other and require mastering their unique attacks. I particularly liked this boss that's 3 skeletons combined into 1. In the second phase, each skeleton covers a portion of the screen (1 in the top, 1 in the center, and 1 at the bottom). They attack with laser beams that can't be dodged, and always attack 2 at a time. In order to dodge them, you need to use your super moves to stay in the 1 portion of the screen that the skeleton is not attacking. This was a great way to make "spamming super moves" an interesting affair and I wish all of the bosses and enemies made spamming super moves as interesting as this. 

While the combat gets slightly stale near the end, thankfully the platforming stays engaging throughout the game. This is some of the best platforming I've seen in any 2-D game. Your character can wall jump and double-jump. Also, the special moves are worked into the platforming since the move that makes you attack up is effectively another jump, and the move that makes you go left/right is crucial for certain platforming sections. Furthermore, your character can dimension swap between 2 dimensions. In 1 dimension there are certain obstacles/platforms while in another dimension they're different. Swapping between these dimension quickly when platforming is crucial to succeeding, and it made the platforming sections so satisfying to beat.

The progression system is well done. Beating enemies awards you currency which you can use to buy stuff at checkpoints. You can buy health ups, energy ups, costumes, etc… You can also find health ups and energy ups in chests while exploring. There are a LOT of chests to scattered throughout the world, so it's always rewarding to go off the beaten path and explore. So you're rewarded for adventuring, so that's fun.

There's a story that's fairly typical. A villain kidnaps a girl and you as the main hero have to save her. What's not so typical are the characters themselves and their dialogue. This game doesn't take itself too seriously and the characters can be genuinely hilarious sometimes. They have unique personalities and there's a lot of pop culture references. There's a scene straight from Star Wars in one scene and I laughed out loud when I saw it. 

Overall, this is a great game with a very strong early game. It's unfortunate that the late game was not as engaging, but what's here is still a great package.

58051737.review:
Pros:
-You're a Luchador
-Easter Eggs... tons of Easter Eggs
-Easy to understand mechanics
-Story isn't too deep, very linear and a wee bit predictable, but you will get immersed (well I did) and you will still get some feels.
-You're a ♥♥♥♥ing Luchador!

Cons:
-Unforgiving, like a good old 80-90's game: a few (or one) false move can destroy you or impede your progress - luckily this is still a modern day game, so they threw you a bone: infinite lives - when you die: you respawn at a checkpoint, your progress beyond the checkpoint is lost, but that's it. no "X4 lives left". -whew.
-Uncomfortable key mappings (this is for gamepad) that cannot be changed. Paired with the former cons, this makes the game more frustrating than it should.

9/10; not giving 'em a 10 not untill they fix the controller problem.

56377376.review:
Guacamelee is a brawler action puzzle platformer, with a heavy emphasis on platforming. While the platforming can get pretty challenging, it isn't near-impossible, like Hollow Knight's Path of Pain. This is pretty much Rayman, except with Luchadores. 
I personally found the start of the game a little dull, because the plot is really just the Mexican version of Mario's quest to save Princess Peach. Plus, combat also started off slow, with only basic hand to hand combat. But thankfully, it got a lot more fun once I unlocked more powers. So many ways to beat your enemies to pulp!

There's also probably 12+ hours of gameplay in this, assuming you attempt to get all the collectibles. 
Guacamelee is a true gem of a platformer, and definitely worth the buy even at full price. You don't even need to take my word for it - considering the amount of effort it takes to get the alternate ending, it actually says a lot about this game that 16% of its players actually made the effort to achieve it. 
While frustrating at times, there's no denying Guacamelee is a ton of fun!

55718974.review:
First of all, I have much more than 3 hours of gameplay. Something like 8 hours I think, but the Steam is only showing 3 hours because I played this game a lot without internet.

When I started playing this game it was in a time I just didn't want to play anything, and other games were not hooking me. But I continued playing because it was a game I could play while doing something else, but after a while a became hooked and used any spare time I had to play it. If you're like me who don't know what to play or do right now, this is a good game to make you play again.

The game is a metroidvania that has a combo-base melee combat, that is somewhat deep and fun. Also, it does not focus a lot on finding your way, since just following the map and the indicators, you'll basically never get lost. It has the doors locked by special powers, but you'll never need to remember, since when you get that upgrade, the game is going to direct you to where you need to be. Since I was a little impatient at the time, I liked it. But at the same time, the other paths leads to not only powerups but fun platforming. I ended up going after almost all powerups.

One very fun thing is the jokes. It's a funny, very silly game, with very clever and adult jokes mixed with the most stupid (and good) jokes you'll ever see. Even if the story isn't good or important, it's characters and dialogues are very fun and made me want to see the game through.

If you want something very deep, maybe this isn't for you, but if you just want to play something that is good and light, this is a great game to play.

55543123.review:
[h1]Overall = 7 / 10[/h1]

A fun and enjoyable metroidvania with a great setting and plenty of jokes / referential humour to make you smirk (or groan) that ultimately struggles to stand out from the crowd.  The game is bright and colourful and a real treat to look at and listen to, but the gameplay, level designs and mechanics all feel a bit flat and basic.  The combat is mostly unsatisfying, either being too easy or too hard, and pulling off combos of special combat moves, which are required to progress through some of the platforming sections, is tricky.  Combat is mostly segregated into small arenas, some of the toughest platforming challenges come out of nowhere, and the bosses are pretty unmemorable.

I enjoyed my shortish time with it and heartily recommend it as a functional and good open platform game.

55443579.review:
A pretty looking metroidvania that isn't as fun as it's bright and colourful.

To get straight to what makes it unfun: a lot of puzzles, area traversals and combat scenarios require very precise usage of ability combos to progress, and most of abilities you unlock in this game are just a variation of charge or jump, and as they pile up you have to perform more torturous actions, like say to tripple jump in one area you hafve to jump, then perform up-charge, and a forward-charge. This is... frustrating, and the game isn't very forgiving about it, with some lengthy precision combat requiring areas sending you way back at start if you make a single mistake. The combat is kinda better since it comes off more close to fighting games than metroidvanias there, but some boss fights and intense battles still require really precise combo-ing to get things done. Honestly this is exactly why I can't recommend the game and have little to not interest in sequel (which I heard is pretty similar in this regard), it's just too frustrating.

Now, the good part: the world is pretty fun, it's like this caricature of Mexico with lots of stereotypical aspects like sombreros and skeletons and, well, the luchadore masked wrestlers play a crucial role in this world, wielding mystical powers and fighting injustices. You end up as one, too. I'm not sure if all these stereotypes and cultural symbols could be considered offensive, if you ask me the game blatantly doesn't take itself serious while at same time shows these cultural aspects in a pretty affectionate manner, everyone from country bumpkins to other strangers are pretty sympathethic even if they portray some negative stereotype. The music is also really on point and memorable. What is a bit annoying is how full of pop culture jokes this game is. Like, very single advertisement or business banner is a reference to other game, which I can forgive as this solidarity with other indies and desire to subtly promote their game, but it doesn't stop at them and the pop culture references are endless.

Overall, I feel like it could have been more forgiving, and while I am sure there will be people who enjoy pulling off precision combos, I really cannot recommend the game. Esp. when there are other metroidvanias like Ori and the Blind Forest which are also pretty but have more interesting abilities and aren't as demanding for precise combo executions.

Although the combat and enemies' RNG on moves can be a bit bullsh*t at times , you have plenty of moves of your own in the arsenal and the checkpoints are established in appropriate locations so you don't have to waste much time walking around the level if you die in one room or at one boss, you can just retry right away. This is by far the best plat-former I've ever played. 
The things i loved -
•  The visuals - I've legit taken 50+ screenshots of the game, every location and set piece is so stunning and beautiful.
•  The combat  - Although you don't have a lot of moves in the first half of the game, the last few hours of the game is f*cking awesome-with a WIDE variety of jumps, attacks and a few more awesome surprises XD.
•  The difficulty - I'm not a big fan of really difficult games, but Guacamelee! hits the sweet spot. Its difficult at the required spots yet rewarding at the same time. Not gonna lie, the boss fights took more than a dozen tries which made the victory more rewarding.
•  The character dialogues - There is no voice acting, but the dialogues are a masterpiece, i constantly found myself cracking up throughout by play-through. (The highlights are the puns)

All in all, a must play for plat-former lover and even if your not i would recommend you try the game! The art-style and combat will keep you hooked.

54842972.review:
This game is by no means a "bad" game, not in the general definition of bad. The artstyle is great, the movement and combat flows well and the music is pretty nice.

My problem with this game, however, is this: 

The Repetition. This game is just repetitive in the worst way. It is (supposed to be) a metroidvania, so you go through areas, fight enemies, collect new powers. Fighting enemies is very repetitive, platforming is simple and - well, that´s it. Puzzles and platforming consist of 90 % walljumping, whereas combat consists of "mash X 3 times for the basic combo, then use one of your 4 special moves, and maybe occasionally grab an enemy". The game is also incredibly easy, and it is one of those wonderful games where you don´t unlock the harder difficulty unless you play through it once (always a genius move in any game!)

While the artstyle is great, the areas are just boring and badly designed. Go through linear hallway, arena appears, fight a couple enemies, walljump up two walls, go through another hallway, arena appears, fight a couple enemies, rinse and repeat. There is never a challenge in the game, you never have to think. The "metroidvania" part of the game is also very light; you learn 4 special moves as the game goes on (as well as two movement abilities), allowing you to break coloured blocks in earlier areas. But the actual discovery aspect of this game is so light that you only find one of four objects behind those walls; health and stamina upgrades, money, or orbs for the different ending.

Really, my problem with the game is just that it is so boring and without drive. It just goes through the motions. Everything is just way too easy and repetitive. Boring forest, lifeless volcano, some snow mountain, a town with 4 buildings you can enter, boring combat, boring bosses, boring story with a bad ending that can only be upgraded by finding 6 hidden orbs.

If the game would be a little more challenging, more creative, would consist of more than just hallway to enemies to simple puzzle/platforming to hallway, then I probably would recommend it; the artstyle and music are the reason why it stings a little to downvote it, too. But I am rating a game here, and it was very hard to find one under the pretty facade. Maybe you will like it more than I did, but buy it on sale if you do.

As for me, it was a boring, uninspired metroidvania-supermegalite, especially compared to some really good similar games like Hollow Knight.

54819563.review:
Guacamelee!, es un juego de plataformas y "Hack and slash" en scroll lateral. En este juego con ambientación mexicana tu misión es avanzar a lo largo de las pantallas para derrotar al jefe final y así rescatar a la "princesa". Guacamelee! es un juego que claramente logra aquello que busca. No pretende llegar a ser el juego insignia del genero, pero con un toque de humor estupendo y una jugabilidad maravillosa se ha hecho un hueco entre los juegos que me han gustado bastante.

De los aspectos a destacar por encima de todo pondría el tema de la presentación de habilidades y el aprendizaje de ellas, es decir que el juego, en este caso presenta varias habilidades que te permitirán mejorar en combate y en plataformeo de manera simultanea, y lo hace de manera ordenada y con una pequeña práctica a lo largo de la aventura para que aprendas a usarlas de la mejor manera y te acostumbres rápido.

El humor y la música están bien llevados a cabo a lo largo de la aventura, y el plataformeo no se hace pesado, lo cual es de valorar, además los cambios de escenario hacen que no se haga pesado en ningún momento.

Como puntos negativos más destacables pondria una historia mas bien pobre (pese a que no sea lo que se viene a buscar en este titulo) y un sistema de teletransportes en el mapa que no me han acabado de convencer y a penas me he visto en la necesidad de usarlos o cuando los necesitaba estaban demasiado lejos.


[b]Mi nota para este juego es: 7.76[/b]

54695588.review:
Well-made little brawler with Metroidvania elements. Guacamelee! follows the classic "save the princess" trope, with a striking visual style, framework dipped in Mexican culture and humor that lands more often than not. There's not a whole lot to say about it; combat is simple button mashing with the option for combos if you're feeling particularly skilled, as well as power moves for both combat and exploration. The campaign takes anywhere from 5 to 8 hours, depending on how much of a completionist you are and the whole thing is just really fun. The side-quests aren't too demanding and add character to the world, there's a whole lot of pick-ups to challenge your OCD and the game is just smooth and amusing from beginning to end.

It's not perfect, though. For one thing, running the game fullscreen causes constant stutters, which means I had to play the game on windowed mode (and borderless doesn't exist, due to the game's age). In fairness, this same issue appeared on Giana Sisters recently as well (when it wasn't a problem before), so there's a chance some accursed Win10 update just broke the game.

Also, the difficulty curve leaves something to be desired. The game is perfectly beatable and it's not overly challenging; however, in its third act, it's choke-full of excruciating platforming sections that rely on split-second reactions with utilizing a number of different moves to traverse the environment and dual-world switching on the fly, which can get tedious. The game has the decency to (usually) not kill you when you fail (it just puts you back on a platform to try again), but it can get frustrating, especially as the controls can screw you over. Same goes for some combat arenas, the design of which can be especially asinine (I'm looking at you, bombs).

Lastly, as beautiful as the game is, it's perfectly possible to lose track of the player character when there are too many enemies on-screen or even during boss battles. The final boss, for example, has a very easy to decipher pattern, but took me way too many tries because the screen got too busy to keep track of what was going on.

Having said all that, I really enjoyed Guacamelee! despite its shortcomings. I picked it up for free (I believe it was a Humble giveaway) and I'm so used to giveaways being utter trash, I was surprised with the level of quality on display here. I'll definitely be picking up the sequel next chance I get.

54509582.review:
Overall a good Metroidvania with unique visuals, Mexican culture, and excellent music themes throughout the experience.  Combat feels very rewarding while you find new ways to string long combos on enemies and being able to dodge at any time keeps fights fast and engaging.  Despite the game's content primarily being fighting it never felt too gratuitous due to the various platforming and side-quest objectives sprinkled about.  

While I appreciated the fact that each area displays it's own separate completion rating of 0%-100% there were times where I felt the unexplored secret areas could have been vaguely shown on the map screen better.  The colored blocks were shown on the map very clearly while narrow tunnels are practically invisible.  Save/Warp icons on the map also caused me to miss progression / secret areas due to the game occasionally placing branching paths near them. 

The difficulty of the game is very easy overall, deaths only reset your progress to a 1 minute progression loss at most, auto-save locations are found on practically every facet of the map + fill your health back to max. Hard mode does a decent job at encouraging a second playthrough of the game.  I appreciated the extra care that went into bosses in that all of them (save from the final boss) play differently in various ways.  The earlier parts of the game are practically the same as normal mode until it ramps up near the end.

Had fun with this and would recommend it as a good starting point for those looking to get into Metroidvanias.   Guacamelee does a good job with it's short and legible map layouts that tells you all you need to know about a level, constant progression via ability unlocks, and very fast loading screens.

54508661.review:
Guacamelee is an extremely stylistic Metroidvania game and It’s great. This game highlights the beauty of Mexican culture so absolutely well in it’s Aztec/Mayan Style of art, clever cultural integrations (Olmec heads as teleporters), and most prominently to me the Soundtrack. Holy shit if you like Mexican music you’ll love this game - very unique twists using D minor in the soundtrack as well. The art design may not be for some though, and is overall simplistic. This game also features a LOT of references to other games which are really fun to find and read.

The game features an ability to swap between the world of the living and the dead which in turn changes the ENTIRE surrounding areas with incredible attention to detail to both art AND sound design. This combined with the other abilities creates some pretty unique puzzles and timing obstacles. However, a few rooms simply don’t have a world of the dead version and thus force you back into the real world. Animations can be a bit unnatural when this happens as well as with ability use near odd geometry, but it’s a decently old game so It makes sense.

Combat is incredibly combo based and really fun to mess around with. There are a multitude of ways to beat up and manipulate your enemies and furthermore manage your intenso bar. The major complaint here are the boss fights. In all honesty they felt extremely drawn out and unfitting to fight. Enemies range from annoying to extremely annoying, which ultimately adds to the pleasure of beating them up like a luchador.

There are a decent amount of collectibles to find and costumes/upgrades to buy, as well as steam workshop integration so you can import your own skins if you want to. Guacamelee does have a simple but charming story and as well as local co-op integration. NPC dialogue is also pretty funny at certain moments.

Guacamelee is the Mexican Metroidvania nobody asked for and I love it.

54097484.review:
Put on your mask and bring friends! 

Guacamelee! is a metroidvania action platforming video game developed and published by DrinkBox Studios.

On the Dia de los Muertos (Day of the Dead), evil skeleton named Carlos Calaca attacks the small village in Mexico and kidnaps El Presidente's Daughter, Lupita. You will play as Juan Aguacate, a simple agave farmer who now becomes a Luchador, with a task of saving her! 

Gameplay is a combination of metroidvania and brawlers. Like all of the games from metroidvania subgenre, Guacamelee has open and non-linear world you can fully explore. Obviously some of the areas are not available at first and you need to progress before entering them, to keep the difficulty and progression system on track! In those areas you can progress in storyline, or start looking for secrets, yet it is better to do that later when you have decent amount of skills. Secrets vary from stamina/health increase, to chests with coins. It's fun to collect them, and they really help you! 

Game has a ton of platformic elements. At first it might look simple enough, as you just have to jump from ledge to ledge, but later on as more abilities are gained, you use them to boost your jumps, wallrun, double jump, dodge specific objects, the usual when it comes to those types of games, so it's not for everyone. 
Coordination is required, and for some, a controller aswell. There is a reason game recommends a controller everytime you launch it. It simply offers better mapping of combos you need to perform, and smaller chance of missing specific buttons because of stress. It's easier to hit bumps and triggers rather than small keys. But it dosen't mean it's impossible to beat it! Look at me, I played the damn thing on keyboard and my fingers are mostly fine, can't say that about mental health so better pick a controller to avoid frustration. 

Combat has same difficulty curve as platforming. At first, enemies are pretty weak and feature two or three types only, you can easily dodge their attacks and defeat them. As you progress, game adds shields, attacks you can't dodge, bigger and tougher enemies, and so on.
Enemies drop coins after being defeated, health orbs to regenerate health!
Because you are a Luchador, there is a ton of combos you can perform, like in most of the brawler games. Throw enemies in the air, combine abilties, avoid attacks!

Abilities you collect are used everywhere. Need to climb onto something? Destroy a specific block or shield? It requires a specific ability. To use them, you need to have stamina, if you run out of it, just wait few seconds and it will recharge! 
Same can't be said about health, to recharge it you either need to hit a checkpoint, or you need to collect health orbs. 

Checkpoints in the game are also shops, in which you can spend coins you collected. Game features two types of those-normal coins are used to upgrade Juan and his skills and silver coins, used to buy costumes, those change the way you look (duh) but also have pros and cons. Regenerate slowly health, but regenerate slower stamina? Deal, yet take more damage
at the same time? It's your choice which costume you will pick!

You need help? Ask a friend to play with you! Game features coop for 4 players, but if I recall, it's only local and you need, obviously, 3 other controllers.
Besides coop you also have Hard Mode, which as name suggest, increases difficulty of the game. And while I didn't notice improved platformic difficulty, fights are definitely harder, with enemies packing a punch. 

It's optimized very well, I had no issues when playing so I can't really complain, can I. 

Because it is set in Mexico, soundtrack composed by Rom Di Prisco and Peter Chapman is filled with traditional Mexican music. It really adds to the game, I loved it! And you can focus on it even more as there is no voice acting in the game. 

Relentless yet enjoyable combat, great platforming gameplay, and fantastic soundtrack, Guacamelee is a must play for metroidvania fans! A bit short. 8/10! 

If you enjoyed reading that review, check out [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31947302/] my curator page! [/url]

54041759.review:
This game definitely has its moments. If you like platformer-metroidvanias, and don't mind punishing difficulty and a more linear experience, this game does have some clever puzzles, interesting combat, and eccentric characters.

Overall, I can't recommend this game because of issues with its controls and difficulty, which drain the fun from what would be an otherwise light and well-paced game.

Probably the first thing you'll notice, is that the player character has binary movement. Either he's sprinting, or he's standing still.  The result is that your control of the character feels imprecise. This isn't a great start for a game that is at least 50% platforming.

The second thing you may notice, is that the inputs seem sluggish. Timing jumps or attacks starts to become very frustrating, since you'll have to do every action what feels like 1/3 of a second in advance, because the game can't keep up. Eventually you get used to it, but this is one of the only games I've experienced this problem with. Tack on overly punitive hit boxes on hazards like spikes, and you'll really start to grind your teeth.

Lastly is the difficulty. The two above factors wouldn't be such a issue if the difficulty of the game wasn't tuned so tightly. By tight, I mean that around 20% of the puzzles in the game are basically tuned with no margin for error. You execute them exactly as the designers intended, or you fail and start over. Each puzzle still feels like it could have been good, but either the timing is too tight, or the number of steps is too many. The result, is that frequently you can complete 90% of the puzzle flawlessly, but you'll end up smashing your face on it repeatedly trying to get though that last 10% over and over. It's not fun, its just tedious and frustrating. Each of these puzzles comes down to rote-memorization and luck, and eventually you'll get through. Some of the combat challenges also suffer from this, but it doesn't really become an issue until near the end of the game.

Overall, while the game doesn't do anything new for the genre, it is well paced and fun for the most-part. If the controls issues and incredibly punishing 10% of the game were removed, I'd be off enjoying it and not sitting here writing this review.

53980310.review:
This is a Platventure, but the hook is that you have Fighter moves as both attacks and ways to reach new areas.  It starts out simple enough, and does a very good job of easing you into new moves and what to do with them.  That said, it gets to be quite challenging by the end, especially if you're trying to grab all of the game's treasures.  This leads to some really cheap moments, and some of the move inputs clash a bit with general design, so there is the occasional frustration.  The combat gradually gets harder, too, especially if you're trying to rack up big combos.  Though the time between hits is very forgiving, and you can get extra hit bonuses for killing enemies or hitting them with special moves, take one hit and your combo ends.  Luckily, they're mostly for personal gratification, and if they do increase the amount of money that you receive - I didn't take notice - it doesn't matter much, because you'll likely have enough to buy all of the upgrades by the end, so long as you're diligent.

Beyond the dynamic combat and clever puzzles, what stands out is the Mexican theme.  It's not too often that you see this in a game, and they did a great job with it.  The way that it's presented is a good way to really get interested in the culture, even if it's not exactly educational; over the few days I played this, I kept subconsciously slipping in and out of Spanish, without being overly tired or stressed.  The music helps with this, too, because it's traditional music that's been remixed to give it an exciting new feel.  The visuals are neat, too, starting out with the usual yellowy desert, but getting into some mysterious ruins, and a whole other world, where all sorts of strange visual phenomena come out to bloom.

The humor's a little hit-or miss, unfortunately.  It's a pretty funny game, overall, and when a joke lands, its over-the-top presentation really makes it pop; by the end, I was still chuckling every time I got a new ability.  A lot of it, though, is semi-funny, but mostly pop culture references (the majority of which are to video games) that don't make any sense here.  Sure, with the luchador theme, a Strong Bad reference makes sense, but there's a broken wall with exposed bricks in the shape of a Mega Man sprite at one point.  Every once in a while, they're funny, just because they come out of nowhere, smack you upside the head, and fly off into the distance before you even figured out what happened, but there are so many that they start to just seem out of place.

All in all, a few unreasonable expectations aside, there isn't anything wrong with it; if you're looking for a fresh, new experience, and don't mind a challenge that's especially high for this subgenre, then give this a go!

53719725.review: Guacamelee is a curiously entertaining and action packed game about a luchador coming back from the dead to rescue the president's daughter. He meets a slew of whacky and comical characters who will aid the luchador in his journey by either teaching him new abilities or guiding him to the right path. Although there is a linear and coherent story that anyone can understand the game itself is open to the player in a more semi metrovania styled open world game where some places require certain abilities and power ups while others don't. You could in theory go wherever you want from the very start although you won't go far. To my surprise I thought that the game would have to heavily rely on the gameplay which I expected to be the average metrovania type but in reality it has a nice balance of story and gameplay. The story being a wild adventure across the desert, rivers, and jungles to save the president's daughter all while facing off with other luchadors and criminals. There are side quests you can partake in but it's all optional in fact none of the ones I've played have really given me anything which is unfortunate because helping the local grandmother in town make her specialty was honestly fun enough to have warranted at least a stupid joke reward. For the gameplay I was pleasantly surprised with the combat; I like the grappling which admittedly I'd use a lot despite it not always being a reliable way to cause damage. I also found the combos interesting but they never really felt like I had to learn them in order to play and win it had always felt like I could just wing it but having the option is still nice. Although the achieving of these combos was rather annoying and cute. In order to learn combos you have to find a luchador chicken (which is just a regular chicken that can speak for some reason) to teach you using the skeleton of a dead luchador. It's hard to master and annoying just to unlock the entirety of a combo move of which I'll probably never use the entire sequence of if not never use it at all. The platforming can be just as difficult at times but thankfully they aren't too hard that it ruins the experience of the game I just think they went a bit too far with the things they expect you to be able to pull off. One thing I really enjoyed about the game was the inclusion of being able to play as a girl luchador to which I did and still am playing only as her. I love those inclusions because although I don't need it to enjoy the game I enjoy it a little more with the inclusion. Don't get me wrong I can play a game where your only playable character is a man but if I had to choose I'd choose a woman. Overall I feel that this game is worth the money it takes to play this game; whether you buy it on sale or simply buy it at full price. I enjoyed it and I know others will and others won't. 53676096.review: Guacamelee is a metroidvania beat-em-up game.  It has a set path that is dictated by various abilities that are necessary for breaking different colored blocks.  The game play is simple but, as the combo teacher will teach you, it can get pretty intense and complex.  Personally, I went the easy way and relied on grappling, but each of my friends found their own play style.  Play styles can be further developed with the addition of various costumes which give buffs and debuffs like better throws but your punches deal less damage.  One of the greatest points, and weakness, of the game is the multiplayer function.  It is always amazing to finally find a game my siblings and I or my friends and I can play together without buying four copies.  However, with Guacamelee, the difficulty drops exponentially with the number of players in the game.  The enemies remain at the same strength and number whether you have one player or four.  This makes it more friendly to players who don't want to learn the 27 hit combos from the teacher but can be boring if you are that one hardcore gamer in the group.  Overall, I rate this a great 9/10.

53197966.review:
Thanks for this one, Humble Bundle. And now, for something completely different.

Es casi difícil demostrar cuánto ha crecido este juego desde que lo instalé y, para ser honesto, al principio no sabía qué esperar. Honestamente pensaba que con un nombre como Guacamelee, pensaba a medias que sería como un juego tipo Smash Brothers, solo para sorprenderme gratamente de que estaba más en la línea de un juego tipo Metroidvania, pero se aferraba a elementos como luchadores enmascarados, El día de los muertos y cosas que realmente muestran la cultura mexicana.

Abandonando ese tema, el juego comienza contigo jugando como Juan, tu típico hombre que solo estaba atendiendo su campo de agave cuando una figura sombría destruye la casa del presidente y luego un grupo de matones secuestró a su hija con la intención de fusionar la tierra de los muertos con la tierra de los vivos. Durante esto, intentaste detener a este grupo, solo para ser enviado rápidamente, pero el destino conspiraría de otra manera. Una máscara reluciente en la cabeza de una estatua le da a Juan una nueva oportunidad de vida, por así decirlo, y desde allí, se te da la fuerza, las habilidades y el misticismo de un luchador, donde puedes infligir movimientos dañinos como un suplex, patea tu Los oponentes se alejan, los acumulan en la tierra o les dan una patada como si fueran un balón de fútbol.

A pesar de todo esto, este juego comienza bastante simple, pero se incrementa con una curva de dificultad de construcción lenta hasta que te enfrentas a todo tipo de peligros locos, como cuchillas de sierra, púas, lava, enemigos con códigos de colores y múltiples golpes. Los enemigos blindados, los que vuelan, los gigantes, los explosivos, algunos que llevan espadas y esquivarán rápidamente cualquier cosa que intentes lanzar, incluidas muchas otras, por lo que es mejor que estés preparado para comenzar a derribar. Pero bueno, no tienes nada de qué preocuparte porque en el camino, te encuentras con varias mejoras para tu salud, resistencia e indicadores de intensidad que puedes comprar en la tienda, o encontrarlos en el enorme mundo así como mejoras para tu arsenal de movimientos, así como una variedad de disfraces que pueden agregar beneficios o aumentar el desafío. Sin dar demasiado lejos, comienza a acumularse en un punto y lo dejaré así. Otra cosa que olvidé mencionar es que cuando se agrega Steam Workshop, incluso puedes agregar disfraces que la gente haya creado.

Ahora, ¿recomiendo esto? Apuestas tu culo a que yo hago. Esta es una agradable sorpresa que no debe perderse. Lo único que puedo decir en contra es que solo hay multijugador local, así que si quieres reunir a algunos amigos de todo el mundo, necesitarás un programa llamado Parsec para que disfruten de la experiencia.

The only joke part about this is that the main body part of the review was written and then translated with Google Translate. So yeah, get this game, ya nerds.

52504346.review:
This "Metroidvania" has a focus on platforming and combat. While not as complex as Super Metroid or Symphony of the Night, the game is easy to pick up and play. Your upgrades amount mostly to health and meter upgrades along with a handful of combat techniques that also double as movement enhancers. 

Though some of the end game platforming can be fairly difficult, most of it is optional and players looking for a relaxing time can find that here. This is doubled by many of the map's quality-of-life features. It shows you your percentage completion of each area (based on number of treasures left), the color-coded blocks and treasures you encounter but don't break, and even a quest marker that points you in the general direction of the next story objective.

The game also has co-op, but unfortunately, it's only for local play. You won't be able to play online with your friends.

Overall, this is a quick, but solid and relaxing title with end game content to challenge those who want to go above and beyond.

[h1] Mexicano, Stylish, Fair and Fun [/h1]

The game did perfect in bringing the Mexican style inside the game, the combat is really, really good.
the humor in this game is well used in the right areas in the game.

I enjoyed the game alot finishing the (EL Infernio) challenges to get a unique combat technique that is only obtainable through finishing this challenges.. and that's fine/fun to me.

That's right that the game has hard areas that'll take you a significant amount of time to pass, but at the end the game will reward you through the new areas + New gameplay techniques that you'd gain throughout your gameplay.. 

[h1] The game is hard, but fair	[/h1]

 no need for you to play the whole new area again just because you died because of a stupid move you did, you respawn just right before the area you died at.. and that's a huge thing to alot of people who don't like to play hard and a bit-challenging games.

[h1]In the end[/h1] 

I absolutely recommend you to play this game if you already got it for free (like me) or if you are thinking of playing a great stylish game that'd take 10-18 hours out of your time.

52077351.review:
Guacamelee! is a metroidvania meets beat em up with a unique art style that is charming and really fun to play. This is videogame at its purest form, great fun with no paywall whatsoever

The Good:
+ The artstyle of this game is just breathtakingly beautiful. The use of color palette in the environment really make this game stand out.
+ The soundtrack is downright amazing. The lively environment is supported by the uplifting music that always plays through the entire 5-6 hours campaign. It might get repetitive to some, but i was too busy enjoying the music to notice.
+ Platformer meets beat em up gameplay that is a cross between castlevania in terms of platforming and streets of rage in terms of fighting. Where other games might have one aspect that is better, Guacamelee! excels in both areas. The controls for this game is excellent, easy to learn but hard to master. Platforming is straightforward in the beginning but as the game progress, Guacamelee! gives the players a lot of platforming-puzzle sequences that are enjoyable and frustrating, but never impossible. Combat is also another thing of highlight for the gameplay, as it can be pretty deep. Like platforming, combat seems like just another button mash at the start but in a few hours time, you'll be using long combos to defeat that gigantic skull titan.
+ The story is really good. Without spoiling anything, it tells a revenge story meets end of the world scenario that is enjoyable to watch from start to finish. A bit of a shame that our main character doesn't talk. The cast of characters that we get to meet on the other hand are laid in variety and hilarious personalities. The goat-man is my personal favorite, reminding me of Rafiki from The Lion King
+ Comedy in this game is just pure gold. It doesn't try too hard to be funny, but tells jokes and lays hilarious scenario at just the right moment.

The Bad:
- A part from a few frustratingly annoying platforming sections and enemy types, this game have very few flaws

The Verdict:
Buy it. Even at full price I feel it is worth every cent. I got it for free and I feel guilty for not spending anything to play this game

51985230.review:
I'm a little embarrassed to admit that I didn't purchase this game, and got it as part of a Humble free giveaway. The only reason I say that is because this game is amazing! 

The summary:
* Super tight platforming and side-scrolling beat-em up game play - no slippy or laggy input on the controls. SUPER TIGHT!
* Metroidvania style game with lots of fun side quests and areas to revisit as you learn more moves.
* Excellent combo system that utilizes pop-ups (ala Marvel V Capcom) that ramps up and becomes more complicated and satisfying the better you get and as you unlock more moves.
* One of the most well written games I've played in years. Laugh out loud dialogue and homages to classic games are everywhere.
* One of the most beautifully stylized games in recent memory.
* Super fluid animations.
* Challenging boss fights, but they are fair. You never feel like you lost because the game was cheesing you. 

Would body slam again. 10/10

[h1]Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition[/h1]
En esta gran aventura encarnaremos la piel de "[b]Juan Guacamole[/b]", un campesino normal y corriente que un día de forma trágica, pierde la vida intentando salvar a la hija del alcalde de su pueblo. En su aventura con estilo metroidvania, donde tendrá que rescatar a su amada, se encontrara con diversos tipos de enemigos y de nuevos poderes con los cuales derrotara a su archi-enemigo "Calaca".
[h1]Lo Bueno:[/h1]

[/list]

[/list]

51945596.review: Got it for free from Humble Bundle a while ago, just give it a try now and kinda regret not doing it sooner. A simple yet fun metroidvania, like the cartoony art style, fitting festive music for Mexican theme, good pace, 10/10. Going for 100% achievements.

51933257.review:
It's hard to find games that are good in both platforming and combat, this game does it wonderfully.

It's another metroidvania, if you played one of these, you'll know what to expect. It has a nice and colorful artstyle, the characters are fun and likeable, the soundtrack is incredible. As you progress, you get new power-ups that you use to break blocks that block your path. They're also needed for breaking enemy shields, doing some sweet combos and going through some very well-made platforming sections. So the game gets better and better with more power-ups, and ends with one final level which will throw everything at you. There were a few small problems I had when I searched for all the remaining chests after beating the game. There was some boring backtracking and many chests had money, but at that point I already bought everything. The difficulty (in normal mode) is just right.

Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition gets a 10/10
Now off to hard mode

Update: Hard mode beaten. It honestly wasn't as hard as I expected it to be. Enemies do more damage, have more health, bosses are a bit different, etc. If you beat normal mode without much trouble and know some good combos, this mode won't be so hard for you.

51828904.review:
Guacamelee is a short and sweet Metroidvania with an emphasis on its combat.  Throughout the game you unlock new moves to both aid you in combat and make new areas of the game accessible through platforming challenges.  Personally I found the platforming more interesting than the combat because the feeling of stringing together half a dozen different attacks to pass a plethora of obstacles was amazing.

The game overall is not particularly challenging though that keeps the pace fast.  It will likely take 6-10 hours to finish the game if you are picking up collectables such as health and stamina upgrades throughout.

The game works well when using a controller or a keyboard.  A small possible issue is that controller bindings cant be modified in-game, though using Steam's controller setup tool this can be fixed.

Overall a solid game which I would recommend to most people who enjoy platforming.

51769536.review: This luchador-styled metroidvania should not be missed! I’ve recommended it to as many people as I possibly can, because I enjoyed it so very much. Vibrant, colourful graphics, very tight controls, enjoyable soundtrack, and fluent combat and movement system all come together with a lighthearted story to make a very memorable and enjoyable experience. The grapple, throw, and punch combo-system leads to rewarding combat that feels engaging instead of repetitive, local co-op is a blast, and the added “El Intenso!” power makes the player, who is already plenty strong, feel like an unstoppable tank. I cannot say enough good things about this game, and would say that this should be part of your library regardless of the kind of games you play. Do yourself or a friend a favour, and pick this gem of a game up, especially when it’s on sale.
